UI.description:
The UI module contains a number of methods for creating simple UI elements
from a SketchUp Ruby script.
UI.name: UI

UI.add_context_menu_handler.description:
The add_context_menu_handler method is used to register a block of code with
SketchUp that will be called when a context menu is to be displayed. The
context menu handler can then display the context menu with the items that
you have added.

Be careful with what you do in a context menu handler. If you perform an
operation takes take a long time, such as traversing the model or selection
in a large model it will delay the menu.

See the contextmenu.rb script in the Plugins/examples directory for an
example.
UI.add_context_menu_handler.name: add_context_menu_handler
return:
the number of context handlers that are
registered

UI.beep.description:
The beep method plays a system beep sound.

The beep method does not accept any arguments nor return any values.
UI.beep.name: beep

UI.create_cursor.description:
The create_cursor method is used to create a cursor from an image file at
the specified location. This must be called from within a custom
Tool. See the Tool class for a complete example.

Since SketchUp 2016 it is possible to provide vector images for the cursors.
SVG format for Windows and PDF format for OS X.
UI.create_cursor.name: create_cursor
parameters:
An x coordinate that is the "hotpoint" for the cursor
computed from the left edge of your cursor image.

A y coordinate that is the "hotpoint" for the cursor
computed from the top edge of the of your cursor image.
For example, a value of (hot_x, hot_y) = (5,10) would
identify the hotpoint of the cursor at 5 pixels from
the left edge of your cursor image and 10 pixels from
the top edge of your cursor image.

UI.inputbox.description:
Creates a dialog box for inputting user information. The dialog box contains
input fields with static text prompts, optional default values, optional
drop down selections, and optional title.

You can also use this method to display drop down lists of options, by
passing an optional param.
UI.inputbox.name: inputbox
return:
An array of returned values if the user did
not cancel the dialog.  If the user canceled the
dialog, false is returned.  The returned values in the
array will be in the same order as the input fields.

UI.inspector_names.description:
The inspector_names method is used to returns the names of all the
inspectors. Inspectors are another name for the various floating dialog
windows that you can activate from withing SketchUp, such as the Materials
window.
UI.inspector_names.name: inspector_names
return:
an array of strings containing the names
of inspectors.

UI.menu.description:
The {.menu} method retrieves a SketchUp's menu object with a given name. This
is the first step toward adding your own custom items to the bottom
of SketchUp's menus.

Valid menu names are: "File", "Edit", "View", "Camera", "Draw", "Tools",
"Window", "Extensions" and "Help".
UI.menu.name: menu
parameters: The name of an existing top level menu.

UI.messagebox.description:
Creates a dialog box containing static text with a series of buttons for
the user to choose from.

Valid message box types are:
- +MB_OK+ - Contains an OK button.
- +MB_OKCANCEL+ - Contains OK and Cancel buttons.
- +MB_ABORTRETRYIGNORE+ - Contains Abort, Retry, and Ignore buttons.
- +MB_YESNOCANCEL+ - Contains Yes, No, and Cancel buttons.
- +MB_YESNO+ - Contains Yes and No buttons.
- +MB_RETRYCANCEL+ - Contains Retry and Cancel buttons.
- +MB_MULTILINE+ - Contains and OK button.

Return values can be any of following:
- +IDOK+
- +IDCANCEL+
- +IDABORT+
- +IDRETRY+
- +IDIGNORE+
- +IDYES+
- +IDNO+

In an +MB_MULTILINE+ message box, the message is displayed as a multi-line
message with scrollbars (as needed). +MB_MULTILNE+ also allows a third string
argument that will be used as the title for the messagebox.
UI.messagebox.name: messagebox
parameters: The message that you want to display.

The message box type, which will be a constant from
the list in the method comments.
return: A number corresponding to what the user selected.

UI.model_info_pages.description:
The model_info_pages method is used to returns the names of all the
available model info pages. These include UI windows such as Components,
Credits, and Units.
UI.model_info_pages.name: model_info_pages
return:
an array of strings containing the names of
model info pages.

UI.openURL.description: The {.openURL} method is used to open the default browser to a URL.
UI.openURL.name: openURL

UI.openpanel.description:
The openpanel method is used to display the Open dialog box. The path that
is returned can then be used inside code to open a text or image file.
See the standard Ruby class File for examples of reading and writing from
disk.

Bug Fixed in SketchUp 2014: Wildcards were not working properly from SU7 to
SU2013. Wildcard filters did not populate the file type dropdown. The filter
string would be shown in the file name field with '*' characters converted to
'_' characters. Note, the format of a wildcard filter string has been changed.
 See the description of the filename parameter below for details.
UI.openpanel.name: openpanel
parameters: The title to apply to the open dialog box.
The default directory for the open panel.

The default filename for the open panel. On Windows, you
can alternatively pass a wildcard filter using this
format: UIname|wildcard||. Additional filter dropdown
list items can be added by adding additional pairs of
filter name and filter like this:
UIname1|wildcard1|UIname2|wildcard2||.
Also multiple wildcard filters can be combined into a
single line using a semicolon-separated list in the
filter field: ui_name|wildcard1;wildcard2||.
return:
the full path and name of the file selected, or
nil if the dialog was canceled.

UI.play_sound.description:
The play_sound method is used to play a sound file. Valid sound files include
.wav and .mp3 files on the Mac and .wav files on the PC.
UI.play_sound.name: play_sound
parameters:
the relative path to the filename from the SketchUp
install directory, or an absolute path to the file. (See
Sketchup.find_support_file for a way to search for a
specific file.)

UI.preferences_pages.description: The preferences_pages method is used to returns the names of all the preferences pages. These include windows like Templates. [SketchUp 2017] "Extensions" page was removed.
UI.preferences_pages.name: preferences_pages
return:
an array of strings containing the names
of preference pages.

UI.refresh_inspectors.description:
Tells SketchUp to refresh all inspectors such as the Component Browser and
the Outliner. This is useful when you need to manually force a refresh after
you've made a change to the document via Ruby. Generally, SketchUp will keep
these in sync for you, but occasionally it does not, such as when
model.start_operation has disabled UI updates.
UI.refresh_inspectors.name: refresh_inspectors

UI.refresh_toolbars.description:
Tells SketchUp to refresh all floating toolbars. This is useful when you need
to manually force a refresh after you've made a change to the document via
Ruby. Generally, SketchUp will keep these in sync for you, but occasionally
it does not, such as when {Sketchup::Model#start_operation} has disabled UI
updates.
This only affects macOS, on Windows the toolbars are always refreshing.
UI.refresh_toolbars.name: refresh_toolbars

UI.savepanel.description:
The savepanel method is used to display the Save dialog box. The path that
is returned can then be used inside code to save out a text or image file.
See the standard Ruby class File for examples of reading and writing from
disk.

Bug Fixed in SketchUp 2014: Wildcards were not working properly from SU7 to
SU2013. Semicolon-separated lists of wildcards did not populate the file type
dropdown. The filter string would be shown in the file name field with '*'
characters converted to '_' characters.
UI.savepanel.name: savepanel
parameters: The title to apply to the save dialog box.
The default directory for the save panel.

The default filename for the save panel. On Windows, you
can alternatively pass a mask, like "*.txt", to have all
the .txt files display. If you want multiple file types
to display, you can supply multiple masks for the
filename and separate them with a semicolon, like this:
"*.txt;*.doc".
return:
the full path and name of the file
selected or nil if the dialog was canceled.

UI.scale_factor.description:
Returns the scaling factor SketchUp uses on high DPI monitors. Useful for
things like {Sketchup::View#draw2d}.
UI.scale_factor.name: scale_factor

UI.select_directory.description:
The {.select_directory} method is used to display the OS dialog for selecting
one or several directories from the file system.
UI.select_directory.name: select_directory
parameters:
The dialog can be customized by providing a hash or named arguments of
options.
return:
A string with the full path of the
directory selected when
:select_multiple option is set to
false otherwise an array of strings
or nil if the user cancelled.

UI.set_cursor.description:
The {.set_cursor} method is used to change the cursor to a new cursor with a
given cursor id. See UI.create_cursor and the Tool class for details
on creating your own tools with arbitrary cursors.

If you call this while a standard SketchUp tool is active, you will not
see your custom cursor, as these tools are constantly setting their
own cursors to indicate SketchUp's state.
UI.set_cursor.name: set_cursor
parameters: The id of the cursor you want to display.

UI.set_toolbar_visible.description:
The set_toolbar_visible method is used to set whether a given toolbar is
visible.  Note that the toolbars and their names are different on the
Mac vs. PC, so be careful and be sure to test when using this method in a
cross-platform script.
UI.set_toolbar_visible.name: set_toolbar_visible
parameters: The name of a Ruby toolbar.
True to make the toolbar visible, false to hide it.
return: true if successful, false if not.

UI.show_extension_manager.description:
The +show_extension_manager+ method is used to display the Extension Manager
dialog.
UI.show_extension_manager.name: show_extension_manager

UI.show_inspector.description:
The show_inspector method is used to display the inspector with the given
name. You can get the list of valid inspectors with UI.inspector_names.
UI.show_inspector.name: show_inspector
parameters: The name of inspector that you want to display.
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful

UI.show_model_info.description: The {.show_model_info} method is used to display the model info dialog for a specific page. You can get the list of valid dialogs with {UI.model_info_pages}. [SketchUp 2014] "Classifications" page was added.
UI.show_model_info.name: show_model_info
parameters: The name of the model info dialog you want to display.

UI.show_preferences.description:
The show_preferences method is used to display a SketchUp preferences dialog.
You can get the list of valid dialogs with {UI.preferences_pages}.
UI.show_preferences.name: show_preferences
parameters: The name of the preferences dialog you want to display.

UI.start_timer.description:
The start_timer method is used to start a timer. This is an effective method
to create a repeating snippet of code for arbitrary animation.

See this blog post for an detailed example of custom animation using timers:
http://sketchupapi.blogspot.com/2008/10/animate-yo-cheese.html

Note that there is a bug that if you open a modal window in a non-repeating
timer the timer will repeat until the window is closed.
UI.start_timer.name: start_timer
parameters: The time in seconds before your code should be called.

true if you want the timer to repeat, false
(or omit) if you do not want it to repeat.

UI.stop_timer.description: The stop_timer method is used to stop a timer based on its id.
UI.stop_timer.name: stop_timer
parameters: The timer id for the timer that you want to stop.

UI.toolbar.description:
The toolbar method is used to get a Ruby toolbar by name. If the toolbar
doesn't exist a new one will be created.
UI.toolbar.name: toolbar
parameters: The name of the Ruby toolbar.

UI.toolbar_names.description:
The toolbar_names method is used to return the name of all the available
native toolbars (this differs between PC and Mac). These toolbar names
do not include Ruby toolbars.
UI.toolbar_names.name: toolbar_names
return: Array of strings representing toolbar names.

UI.toolbar_visible?.description:
The toolbar_visible? method is used to determine whether a given toolbar is
visible. Note that the toolbars and their names are different on the
Mac vs. PC, so be careful and be sure to test when using this method in a
cross-platform script.
UI.toolbar_visible?.name: toolbar_visible?
parameters: The name of a native toolbar.

UI::Command.description:
The Command class is the preferred class for adding tools to the menus and
Ruby toolbars. For example, you could add a menu item and pass it a code
block directly, or you could first create a Command.

Using Commands gives you greater control over how the item works in the UI,
and it allows multiple spots in the UI to call the same code. For example,
You might want a toolbar button and a context-click menu item to both point
to the same command, and to control the tooltip and its "graying" from
a single spot in your code.
UI::Command.name: Command

UI::Command#large_icon.description:
The large_icon method returns the icon file for the command's
large icon.
UI::Command#large_icon.name: large_icon
return: the path to the large icon.

UI::Command#large_icon=.description:
The large_icon= method is used to identify the icon file for the command's
large icon. large icons should be 32x32 pixel images for best display
quality.

Since SketchUp 2016 it is possible to provide vector images for the command.
SVG format for Windows and PDF format for OS X. Since the vector images scale
for both small and large icon sizes, you may choose to use only one vector
image for both variants.
UI::Command#large_icon=.name: large_icon=
parameters: The path to the large icon.

UI::Command#menu_text.description: The menu_text method returns the menu item name for the command.
UI::Command#menu_text.name: menu_text

UI::Command#menu_text=.description: The menu_text= method is used to set the menu item name for the command.
UI::Command#menu_text=.name: menu_text=
parameters: A string representing the menu item for the command.

UI::Command#set_validation_proc.description:
The {#set_validation_proc} method allows you to change whether the command
is enabled, checked, etc. For instance, the command toggling a dialog window
may be displayed as checked while the dialog is open.
UI::Command#set_validation_proc.name: set_validation_proc

UI::Command#small_icon.description:
The small_icon method returns the icon file for the command's
small icon.
UI::Command#small_icon.name: small_icon

UI::Command#small_icon=.description:
The small_icon= method is used to identify the icon file for the command's
small icon. Small icons should be 24x24 pixel images for best display
quality.

Since SketchUp 2016 it is possible to provide vector images for the cursors.
SVG format for Windows and PDF format for OS X. Since the vector images scale
for both small and large icon sizes, you may choose to use only one vector
image for both variants.
UI::Command#small_icon=.name: small_icon=
parameters: A path to the small icon.

UI::Command#status_bar_text.description:
The status_bar_text method returns the status bar text for the
command.
UI::Command#status_bar_text.name: status_bar_text

UI::Command#status_bar_text=.description:
The status_bar_text= method is used to set the status bar text for the
command.
UI::Command#status_bar_text=.name: status_bar_text=
parameters:
The text that will appear on the status bar when the
cursor is over the command's menu item.

UI::Command#tooltip.description: The tooltip method returns command item's tooltip text.
UI::Command#tooltip.name: tooltip

UI::Command#tooltip=.description:
The tooltip= method is used to define a command item's tooltip text. Tooltips
will appear when the command is attached to a tool bar and the user hovers
their cursor over the icon.
UI::Command#tooltip=.name: tooltip=

UI::Command.new.description: The new method is used to create a new command.
UI::Command.new.name: new
parameters:
The text that will appear for this command's menu item
if it appears on a menu.

UI::HtmlDialog.description:
The Ruby HtmlDialog class allows you to create and interact with HTML dialog
boxes from Ruby. This is the best way to generate complex, embedded UIs
inside SketchUp, but it does generally require HTML and JavaScript expertise.

If your goal is to simple display a website to your users, consider using
{UI#openURL}, which will show them a web page in their default browser rather
than inside a dialog in SketchUp.

The left, top, width, height etc. dimensions of the dialog are in logical
units. This means you provide the units as if they where on a monitor with
"normal" DPI. The units given will be multiplied by the same factor as
returned by {UI.scale_factor}.

For usage examples, including how to migrate from the old WebDialog class,
see https://github.com/SketchUp/htmldialog-examples.
UI::HtmlDialog.name: HtmlDialog

UI::HtmlDialog#add_action_callback.description:
The {#add_action_callback} method establishes a Ruby callback method that your
html dialog can call to perform some function.

Use the +sketchup.callback_method_name+ to invoke the callback method from your
html dialog. Your JavaScript in the html dialog will invoke the callback with
the same number of arguments.

The call is asynchronous. JavaScript call might return before Ruby callback
even called. Use +onCompleted+ callback to get notified for completion.

Basic types such as booleans, numbers, strings, arrays and hashes are
automatically converted between Ruby and JavaScript.
UI::HtmlDialog#add_action_callback.name: add_action_callback
parameters:
The name of the callback method to be
invoked from the html dialog.
return:
true if action added successfully, false
otherwise.

UI::HtmlDialog#bring_to_front.description:
The {#bring_to_front} method is used to bring the window to the front,
putting it on top of other windows even if its minimized.
UI::HtmlDialog#bring_to_front.name: bring_to_front

UI::HtmlDialog#center.description:
The {#center} method is used to center the HtmlDialog relative to the active
model window. If there is no active model window, this function doesn't do
anything.
UI::HtmlDialog#center.name: center

UI::HtmlDialog#close.description: The {#close} method is used to close a dialog box.
UI::HtmlDialog#close.name: close

UI::HtmlDialog#execute_script.description:
The {#execute_script} method is used to execute a JavaScript string on the
html dialog asynchronously.
UI::HtmlDialog#execute_script.name: execute_script
parameters: The JavaScript script to execute on the HtmlDialog.

UI::HtmlDialog#initialize.description:
The new method is used to create a new HtmlDialog.

The +properties+ hash accepts an optional key +style+ where the value is
one of:

[+UI::HtmlDialog::STYLE_DIALOG+]   HtmlDialog stays at the top of SketchUp.

[+UI::HtmlDialog::STYLE_WINDOW+]   HtmlDialog can go behind SketchUp and
                                   doesn't disappear when SketchUp looses
                                   focus.

[+UI::HtmlDialog::STYLE_UTILITY+]  HtmlDialog is shown with small titlebar
                                   and stays on top of SketchUp.
UI::HtmlDialog#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
A hash containing the initial properties of
the newly created dialog.

UI::HtmlDialog#set_can_close.description:
The {#set_can_close} method is used to attach a block that is executed just
before closing, this block has to return a boolean, if the block returns
false the close will be canceled.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_can_close.name: set_can_close

UI::HtmlDialog#set_file.description:
The {#set_file} method is used to identify a local HTML file to display in the
HtmlDialog.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_file.name: set_file
parameters: The filename for the HtmlDialog file (HTML file)

UI::HtmlDialog#set_html.description:
The {#set_html} method is used to load a HtmlDialog with a string of provided
HTML.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_html.name: set_html
parameters:
A string of valid html to display in your
HtmlDialog.

UI::HtmlDialog#set_on_closed.description:
The {#set_on_closed} method is used to attach a block that will be
executed when a dialog is already in the process of closing, do any last
minute operations within this block such as saving the current state.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_on_closed.name: set_on_closed

UI::HtmlDialog#set_position.description:
The {#set_position} method is used to set the position of the HtmlDialog
relative to the screen, in pixels.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_position.name: set_position
parameters: The number of pixels from the left.
The number of pixels from the top of the screen.

UI::HtmlDialog#set_size.description: The {#set_size} method is used to set the size of the HtmlDialog, in pixels.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_size.name: set_size

UI::HtmlDialog#set_url.description:
The {#set_url} method is used to load a HtmlDialog with the content at a
specific URL. This method allows you to load web sites in a HtmlDialog.
UI::HtmlDialog#set_url.name: set_url
parameters: The URL for a specific web site.

UI::HtmlDialog#show.description: The {#show} method is used to display a non-modal dialog box.
UI::HtmlDialog#show.name: show

UI::HtmlDialog#show_modal.description: The {#show_modal} method is used to display a modal dialog box.
UI::HtmlDialog#show_modal.name: show_modal

UI::HtmlDialog#visible?.description:
The {#visible?} method is useful to tell if the dialog is shown and still
alive, if the dialog is minimized or not visible on the screen this will
still return +true+.
UI::HtmlDialog#visible?.name: visible?
return: Returns true if the dialog is open.

UI::Notification.description:
UI::Notification objects allows you to show native notifications in the
desktop. Notifications can have a message, icon and accept and/or dismiss
buttons with callback blocks.
UI::Notification.name: Notification

UI::Notification#icon_name.description:
Gets the icon name, this is the path that will be used to get the icon from
the file system path.
UI::Notification#icon_name.name: icon_name

UI::Notification#icon_name=.description:
Sets the icon path, this icon will be loaded from the path give, the path
has to be a local filesystem path.
UI::Notification#icon_name=.name: icon_name=
parameters: String providing the icon filesystem path.

UI::Notification#icon_tooltip.description:
Gets the icon Tooltip, this is the string that appear when the mouse is over
the icon.
UI::Notification#icon_tooltip.name: icon_tooltip

UI::Notification#icon_tooltip=.description:
Sets the icon Tooltip, this string will appear when the mouse is over the
icon.
UI::Notification#icon_tooltip=.name: icon_tooltip=
parameters: String providing the new icon Tooltip.

UI::Notification#initialize.description:
The new method is used to create a new {UI::Notification}.

In order to insert line breaks into the message you need to use +\\r\\n+.
UI::Notification#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
Required sketchup_extension
to identify the sender.
Optionally set a path to an image.

UI::Notification#message=.description:
Sets a new message. Notifications are meant for quick & brief messages.
Remember that they disappear automatically.
UI::Notification#message=.name: message=

UI::Notification#on_accept.description:
Shows a button in the notification with the given title and callback block,
both arguments are required.
UI::Notification#on_accept.name: on_accept
parameters: Sets the title of the button.

Sets the action callback, this will be called when
the user clicks on the dismiss button.

UI::Notification#on_dismiss.description:
Shows a button in the notification with the given title and callback block.
Both arguments are required. This callback is only called if you press the
Dismiss button, not when the time runs out and the notification automatically
disappears.
UI::Notification#on_dismiss.name: on_dismiss
parameters: Sets the title of the button.

Sets the action callback, this will be called when
the user clicks on the dismiss button.

UI::Notification#show.description:
Shows the notification. If not interacted with, the notification will
disappear without calling any callbacks.
UI::Notification#show.name: show

UI::Toolbar.description:
The Toolbar class contains methods to create and manipulate SketchUp
toolbars in Ruby. Toolbars are collections of buttons that you can use
to activate custom Tools or ruby scripts.

Also see the Command object for details on creating "commands" which
can be called from your toolbars.
UI::Toolbar.name: Toolbar

UI::Toolbar#add_item.description: The add_item method is used to add an item to the toolbar.
UI::Toolbar#add_item.name: add_item
parameters:
A Command object representing the command to add to the
toolbar.
return: the toolbar where the command was just added

UI::Toolbar#add_separator.description: The add_separator method is used to add a line separator to the toolbar.
UI::Toolbar#add_separator.name: add_separator
return: the toolbar where the line separator was just added

UI::Toolbar#count.description: The {#count} method is inherited from the +Enumerable+ mix-in module.
UI::Toolbar#count.name: count

UI::Toolbar#each.description:
The each method is used to iterate through all of the commands
attached to a toolbar.
UI::Toolbar#each.name: each

UI::Toolbar#get_last_state.description:
The get_last_state method is used to determine if the toolbar was hidden or
visible in the previous session of SketchUp.

Valid states are 1 for visible, 0 for hidden, -1 for before never shown.
UI::Toolbar#get_last_state.name: get_last_state
return: the last state of the toolbar (see comments)

UI::Toolbar#hide.description: The hide method is used to hide the toolbar on the user interface.
UI::Toolbar#hide.name: hide

UI::Toolbar#length.description: The {#length} method returns the number of items in the toolbar.
UI::Toolbar#length.name: length

UI::Toolbar#name.description: The name method returns the name of the toolbar.
UI::Toolbar#name.name: name

UI::Toolbar#restore.description:
The restore method is used to reposition the toolbar to its previous
location and show if not hidden.
UI::Toolbar#restore.name: restore

UI::Toolbar#show.description: The show method is used to display the toolbar in the user interface.
UI::Toolbar#show.name: show

UI::Toolbar#size.description: The {#size} method is an alias of {#length}.
UI::Toolbar#size.name: size

UI::Toolbar#visible?.description: The visible? method is used to find out if a toolbar is currently visible.
UI::Toolbar#visible?.name: visible?

UI::Toolbar.new.description: The new method creates a new Toolbar object.
UI::Toolbar.new.name: new
parameters: The name for the new toolbar.

UI::WebDialog.description:
The Ruby WebDialog class allows you to create and interact with DHTML dialog
boxes from Ruby.

If your goal is to simply display a website to your users, consider using
{UI.openURL}, which will show them a web page in their default browser rather
than inside a dialog in SketchUp.

See this blog post for a detailed, step-by-step example:
http://sketchupapi.blogspot.com/2008/02/sharing-data-between-sketchup-ruby-and.html

Under Windows the IE render mode is different in webdialogs than from what
you see in the normal browser. It will by default pick an older render mode
and different versions of SketchUp will use different modes. In order to
reliably control the render mode of your webdialogs under Windows you need to
insert a special META compatibility tag:

  // To always force the latest version available:
  <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"/>

  // To lock to a specific IE version:
  <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=8"/>

Starting with SketchUp 2013, you can embed a special HTML link in your dialog
that will launch Extension Warehouse and show a specified extension's page.
This can be useful if your extension has a dependency on another one and you
would like to direct the user to install that extension.

For example, to launch an extension's page whose URL is:
http://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/advanced-camera-tools
The link would be:
UI::WebDialog.name: WebDialog

UI::WebDialog#add_action_callback.description:
The add_action_callback method establishes a Ruby callback method that your
web dialog can call to perform some function.

Use the skp:callback_method_name to invoke the callback method from your
webdialog. Your JavaScript in the webdialog will invoke the callback method
with a string representing arguments to the callback method.

Note that you're sending data down to Ruby as a single string that's
passed via the window.location bar. In Internet Explorer on PC, there is
a length limit of 2038 characters for this bar, so if you're
needing to pass large data down you might consider using get_element_value
to pull in a longer string from a hidden input field in the HTML.
UI::WebDialog#add_action_callback.name: add_action_callback
parameters:
The name of the callback method to be invoked from the
webdialog.

UI::WebDialog#allow_actions_from_host.description:
By default, actions are only allowed on the host where the webdialog is
displayed. The allow_actions_from_host method is used to selectively allow
actions to take place on a host remote from the host where the webdialog
exists. If the webdialog is local, no remote host is allowed unless you use
this method.
UI::WebDialog#allow_actions_from_host.name: allow_actions_from_host
parameters:
The name (domain) of the host that your webdialog can
access safely.

UI::WebDialog#bring_to_front.description:
The bring_to_front method is used to bring the webdialog to the front of all
the windows on the desktop. See show_modal for how to ensure that your
WedDialogs are on top.
UI::WebDialog#bring_to_front.name: bring_to_front

UI::WebDialog#close.description: The close method is used to close the webdialog.
UI::WebDialog#close.name: close

UI::WebDialog#execute_script.description:
The execute_script method is used to execute a JavaScript string on the web
dialog.
UI::WebDialog#execute_script.name: execute_script
parameters: The JavaScript script to execute on the webdialog.

UI::WebDialog#get_default_dialog_color.description:
The get_default_dialog_color method is used to get the default dialog color
for the web dialog.
UI::WebDialog#get_default_dialog_color.name: get_default_dialog_color
return: a six digit hexidecimal number representing the color

UI::WebDialog#get_element_value.description:
The get_element_value method is used to get a value, with a given
element_id, from the web dialog's DOM.
UI::WebDialog#get_element_value.name: get_element_value
parameters: The name of the element in your HTML code.
return: a string containing the retrieved value.

UI::WebDialog#initialize.description: The +new+ method is used to create a new webdialog.
UI::WebDialog#initialize.name: initialize

UI::WebDialog#max_height.description:
The max_height method is used to get the maximum height that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#max_height.name: max_height

UI::WebDialog#max_height=.description:
The max_height= method is used to set the maximum height that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#max_height=.name: max_height=

UI::WebDialog#max_width.description:
The max_width method is used to get the maximum width that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#max_width.name: max_width

UI::WebDialog#max_width=.description:
The max_width= method is used to set the maximum width that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#max_width=.name: max_width=

UI::WebDialog#min_height.description:
The min_width method is used to get the minimum height that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#min_height.name: min_height

UI::WebDialog#min_height=.description:
The min_height= method is used to set the minimum height that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#min_height=.name: min_height=

UI::WebDialog#min_width.description:
The min_width method is used to get the minimum width that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#min_width.name: min_width

UI::WebDialog#min_width=.description:
The min_width= method is used to set the minimum width that the user is
allowed to resize the dialog to.
UI::WebDialog#min_width=.name: min_width=

UI::WebDialog#navigation_buttons_enabled.description:
The navigation_buttons_enabled= method is used to set whether the home, next,
and back buttons are visible at the top of the WebDialog on the mac. This
method has no use on the PC, as these buttons are never displayed.
UI::WebDialog#navigation_buttons_enabled.name: navigation_buttons_enabled=

UI::WebDialog#navigation_buttons_enabled.description:
The navigation_buttons_enabled? method is used to get whether the home, next,
and back buttons are visible at the top of the WebDialog on the mac. This
method has no use on the PC, as these buttons are never displayed.

On the mac, this defaults to true for new WebDialogs.
UI::WebDialog#navigation_buttons_enabled.name: navigation_buttons_enabled?

UI::WebDialog#post_url.description:
The post_url method is used to send the data to a url using the HTTP POST
method.
UI::WebDialog#post_url.name: post_url
parameters: The url to send the data.

UI::WebDialog#screen_scale_factor.description:
The screen_scale_factor method returns the ratio of screen pixels to logical
window units (called 'points' on Mac) for the screen this WebDialog is
currently in. On a retina screen Mac, this ratio will be greater than 1.0.
On Windows this always return 1.0.
UI::WebDialog#screen_scale_factor.name: screen_scale_factor

UI::WebDialog#set_background_color.description:
The set_background_color method is used to set the background color for the
webdialog.
UI::WebDialog#set_background_color.name: set_background_color

UI::WebDialog#set_file.description:
The {#set_file} method is used to identify a local HTML file to display in
the webdialog.
UI::WebDialog#set_file.name: set_file
parameters: The filename for the webdialog file (HTML file).
A path that filename is relative to.

UI::WebDialog#set_full_security.description:
The set_full_security method is used to place the WebDialog into a higher
security mode where remote URLs and plugins (such as Flash) are not allowed
inside the browser. This defaults to false when a new WebDialog is created.
UI::WebDialog#set_full_security.name: set_full_security

UI::WebDialog#set_html.description:
The set_html method is used to load a webdialog with a string of provided
HTML.
UI::WebDialog#set_html.name: set_html
parameters: A string of valid html to display in your webdialog.

UI::WebDialog#set_on_close.description:
The set_on_close method is used to establish one or more activities to
perform when the dialog closes (such as saving values stored in the dialog).
UI::WebDialog#set_on_close.name: set_on_close

UI::WebDialog#set_position.description:
The set_position method is used to set the position of the webdialog
relative to the screen, in pixels.
UI::WebDialog#set_position.name: set_position
parameters: The number of pixels from the left.
The number of pixels from the top of the screen.

UI::WebDialog#set_size.description: The set_size method is used to set the size of the webdialog, in pixels.
UI::WebDialog#set_size.name: set_size

UI::WebDialog#set_url.description:
The set_url method is used to load a webdialog with the content at a
specific URL. This method allows you to load web sites in a webdialog.
UI::WebDialog#set_url.name: set_url
parameters: The URL for a specific web site.

UI::WebDialog#show.description: The show method is used to display a non-modal dialog box.
UI::WebDialog#show.name: show

UI::WebDialog#show_modal.description:
The show_modal method is used to display a modal dialog box. In SketchUp 6
and 7, this behaves differently on Mac vs. PC. On the PC, it shows a truly
modal dialog, meaning so long as the WebDialog is visible, no input can be
performed elsewhere inside SketchUp. On the Mac, "modal" WebDialogs do not
behave this way, but instead are "always on top" of other windows.
UI::WebDialog#show_modal.name: show_modal

UI::WebDialog#visible?.description: The visible? method is used to tell if the webdialog is currently shown.
UI::WebDialog#visible?.name: visible?

UI::WebDialog#write_image.description:
The write_image method is used to grab a portion of the web dialog screen and
save the image to the given file path.
UI::WebDialog#write_image.name: write_image
parameters: The destination path of the saved image.

Specifies what method to use when saving the image. For
JPG/JPEG images, this specifies the image quality and
can range from 1 to 100. For PNG images this specifies
the compression algorithm: <4 (best speed), 4-8
(default), or >=9 (best compression).

The x coordinate of the upper left corner of the
region to grab.

The x coordinate of the upper left corner of the
region to grab.

The x coordinate of the lower right corner of the
region to grab.

The x coordinate of the lower right corner of the
region to grab.

Geom.description:
The Geom module defines a number of Module methods that let you perform
different geometric operations.

The methods in this module take lines
and planes as arguments. There is no special class for representing lines or
planes. Arrays are used for both.

A line can be represented as either an Array of a point and a
vector, or as an Array of two points.
  line1 = [Geom::Point3d.new(0, 0, 0), Geom::Vector3d.new(0, 0, 1)]
  line2 = [Geom::Point3d.new(0, 0, 0), Geom::Point3d.new(0, 0, 100)]

A plane can be represented as either an Array
of a point and a vector, or as an Array of 4 numbers that give the
coefficients of a plane equation.
  plane1 = [Geom::Point3d.new(0, 0, 0), Geom::Vector3d.new(0, 0, 1)]
  plane2 = [0, 0, 1, 0]

There are several good books on 3D math if you are new to
the concepts of a line, plane, and vector.
Geom.name: Geom

Geom.closest_points.description:
The {.closest_points} method is used to compute the closest points on two
lines.

line.
Geom.closest_points.name: closest_points
return:
An array of two points. The
first point is on the first line and the second point is on the second

Geom.fit_plane_to_points.description: The {.fit_plane_to_points} method is used to compute a plane that is a best fit to an array of points. If more than three points are given some of the points may not be on the plane. The plane is returned as an {Array} of 4 numbers which are the coefficients of the plane equation Ax + By + Cz + D = 0.
Geom.fit_plane_to_points.name: fit_plane_to_points

Geom.intersect_line_line.description: The {.intersect_line_line} computes the intersection of two lines.
Geom.intersect_line_line.name: intersect_line_line
return:
The intersection point. Returns +nil+ if they
do not intersect.

Geom.intersect_line_plane.description:
The {.intersect_line_plane} method is used to compute the intersection of a
line and a plane.
Geom.intersect_line_plane.name: intersect_line_plane
return:
A Point3d object. Returns +nil+ if they do not
intersect.

Geom.intersect_plane_plane.description:
The {.intersect_plane_plane} method is used to compute the intersection of
two planes.
Geom.intersect_plane_plane.name: intersect_plane_plane
return:
A line where the planes
intersect if successful. Returns +nil+ if the planes do not intersect.

Geom.linear_combination.description:
The {.linear_combination} method is used to compute the linear combination of
points or vectors.

A linear combination is a standard term for vector math. It is defined as
vector = weight1 * vector1 + weight2 * vector2.
Geom.linear_combination.name: linear_combination

Geom.point_in_polygon_2D.description:
The {.point_in_polygon_2D} method is used to determine whether a point is
inside a polygon. The z component of both the point you're checking and
the points in the polygon are ignored, effectively making it a 2-d check.
Geom.point_in_polygon_2D.name: point_in_polygon_2D
parameters:
An array of points that represent the
corners of the polygon you are checking against.

Pass true if a point on the border should be
counted as inside the polygon.
return: +true+ if the point is inside the polygon.

Geom.tesselate.description: Tessellates a polygon, represented as a collection of 3D points. Can include holes by providing collections of points describing the inner loops. This is intended to be used for planar polygons. Useful to draw concave polygons using {Sketchup::View#draw} or {Sketchup::View#draw2d}. It can also be useful for importers where the input format describes only the loops for a polygon and you want to work with a collection of triangles. Polygon with two holes, one empty and one filled: (See "Drawing a polygon with holes from a custom tool" example) rdoc-image:images/geom-tesselation-polygon-with-holes.png
Geom.tesselate.name: tesselate
return:
an array of points with a stride of three
representing a set of triangles.

Geom::BoundingBox.description:
Bounding boxes are three-dimensional boxes (eight corners), aligned with the
axes, that surround entities within your model. There is a default
bounding box for any new model that will surround all entities,
including all groups and components. Additionally, there are
bounding boxes for Drawingelement objects, including components and groups.
Bounding boxes are only large enough to exactly bound the entities within
your model, group, or component.

You can also create arbitrary BoundingBox objects by calling BoundingBox.new.
Geom::BoundingBox.name: BoundingBox

Geom::BoundingBox#add.description:
The add method is used to add a point, vertex, or other bounding boxes to the
bounding box. The size of the bounding box will increase as necessary to
accommodate the new items.

Adding one point to an empty bounding box does not increase the size of the
bounding box. You must add at least two points before methods such as
BoundingBox.diagonal will return a size greater than zero.
Geom::BoundingBox#add.name: add

Geom::BoundingBox#center.description:
The center method is used to retrieve the Point3d object at the center of
the bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#center.name: center
return:
the Point3d at the center of the bounding box
if successful

Geom::BoundingBox#clear.description:
The clear method is used to clear a bounding box.

A cleared BoundingBox does not have a size greater than zero until you add
at least two points or another bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#clear.name: clear
return: the BoundingBox object which was cleared

Geom::BoundingBox#contains?.description:
This method is used to determine if a bounding box contains a specific
Point3d or BoundingBox object.
Geom::BoundingBox#contains?.name: contains?

Geom::BoundingBox#corner.description:
The corner method is used to retrieve a point object at a specified corner
of the bounding box.

There are 8 corners to a bounding box, identified by the numbers 0 through 7.
Points are returned in the currently set units (inches, by default). These
are which index refers to which corner:

  - 0 = [0, 0, 0] (left front bottom)
  - 1 = [1, 0, 0] (right front bottom)
  - 2 = [0, 1, 0] (left back bottom)
  - 3 = [1, 1, 0] (right back bottom)
  - 4 = [0, 0, 1] (left front top)
  - 5 = [1, 0, 1] (right front top)
  - 6 = [0, 1, 1] (left back top)
  - 7 = [1, 1, 1] (right back top)
Geom::BoundingBox#corner.name: corner
parameters:
A number (from 0 to 7) representing point at the
corner you want to retrieve.

Geom::BoundingBox#depth.description: The {#depth} method is used to retrieve the Z extents of the bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#depth.name: depth

Geom::BoundingBox#diagonal.description:
The {#diagonal} method is used to get the length of the diagonal of the
bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#diagonal.name: diagonal
return:
the size of the diagonal for the bounding
box

Geom::BoundingBox#empty?.description:
The empty? method is used to determine if a bounding box is empty (such as
if the bounds have not been set.) This returns the opposite of the valid?
method.
Geom::BoundingBox#empty?.name: empty?

Geom::BoundingBox#height.description: The {#height} method is used to retrieve the Y extent of the bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#height.name: height

Geom::BoundingBox#initialize.description: The new method is used to create a new, empty, bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::BoundingBox#intersect.description:
The intersect method is used to retrieve a bounding box that is the result
of intersecting one bounding box with another.
Geom::BoundingBox#intersect.name: intersect
parameters: A second boundbox which might intersect boundingbox1.
return:
the resulting BoundingBox object if
successful, an empty BoundingBox object if unsuccessful.

Geom::BoundingBox#max.description:
The max method is used to retrieve the Point3d object where x, y and z are
maximum in the bounding box.

If you attempt to call the max method on an empty bounding box, you will
receive a very large negative number.
Geom::BoundingBox#max.name: max
return:
a Point3d object representing the point where
x, y, and z are the maximum in the bounding box.

Geom::BoundingBox#min.description:
The min method is used to retrieve the Point3d where x, y and z are minimum
in the bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#min.name: min
return:
a Point3d object representing the point where
x, y, and z are the maximum in the bounding box.

Geom::BoundingBox#valid?.description:
The valid method is used to determine if a bounding box is valid (contains
points).
Geom::BoundingBox#valid?.name: valid?

Geom::BoundingBox#width.description: The {#width} method is used to retrieve the X extent of the bounding box.
Geom::BoundingBox#width.name: width

Geom::Bounds2d.description:
The bounds2d class represents an axis aligned bounding box represented by
two {Geom::Point2d} objects, upper left and lower right positions. The
units utilized in the creation and modification {Geom::Bounds2d} are inches.
Geom::Bounds2d.name: Bounds2d

Geom::Bounds2d#==.description:
The {#==} method checks to see if the two {Geom::Bounds2d}s are equal. This
checks whether the point values are the same

Geom::Bounds2d#height.description: The {#height} method returns the height of the {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#height.name: height

Geom::Bounds2d#lower_right.description:
The {#lower_right} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the lower right
corner of the {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#lower_right.name: lower_right

Geom::Bounds2d#set!.description:
The {#set!} method sets the {Geom::Bounds2d} to match another one.
The argument is anything that can be converted into a {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#set!.name: set!

Geom::Bounds2d#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method returns an array which contains the {Geom::Point2d} that
define the {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::Bounds2d#upper_left.description:
The {#upper_left} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the upper left corner
of the {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#upper_left.name: upper_left

Geom::Bounds2d#width.description: The {#width} method returns the width of the {Geom::Bounds2d}.
Geom::Bounds2d#width.name: width

Geom::LatLong.description:
The LatLong class contains various methods for creating and manipulating
latitude and longitude coordinates.
Geom::LatLong.name: LatLong

Geom::LatLong#initialize.description: The new method creates a LatLong object.
Geom::LatLong#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::LatLong#latitude.description: The Latitude method retrieves the latitude coordinate from a LatLong object.
Geom::LatLong#latitude.name: latitude

Geom::LatLong#longitude.description:
The Latitude method retrieves the longitude coordinate from a LatLong
object.
Geom::LatLong#longitude.name: longitude

Geom::LatLong#to_a.description: The {#to_a} method converts a LatLong object to an array of two values.
Geom::LatLong#to_a.name: to_a
return: an array of latitude and longitude

Geom::LatLong#to_s.description: The {#to_s} method converts a LatLong object to a {String}.
Geom::LatLong#to_s.name: to_s

Geom::LatLong#to_utm.description: The to_utm method converts a LatLong object to a UTM object.
Geom::LatLong#to_utm.name: to_utm

Geom::OrientedBounds2d.description:
The OrientedBounds2d class is a bounding box represented by four
{Geom::Point2d} objects, upper left, upper right, lower left and lower right
positions.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d.name: OrientedBounds2d

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#==.description:
The {#==} method checks to see if the two {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}s are
equal. This checks whether the point values are the same.

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#lower_left.description:
The {#lower_left} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the lower left
corner of the {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d#lower_left.name: lower_left

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#lower_right.description:
The {#lower_right} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the lower right
corner of the {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d#lower_right.name: lower_right

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method returns an array which contains the {Geom::Point2d} that
define the {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#upper_left.description:
The {#upper_left} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the upper left corner
of the {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d#upper_left.name: upper_left

Geom::OrientedBounds2d#upper_right.description:
The {#upper_right} method returns the {Geom::Point2d} of the upper right
corner of the {Geom::OrientedBounds2d}.
Geom::OrientedBounds2d#upper_right.name: upper_right

Geom::Point2d.description:
The {Geom::Point2d} class allows you to work with a point in 2D space.
{Geom::Point2d} is a series of values representing x and y coordinates.

The values are specified as +[x, y]+. For example [1, 1].
To create a point call +Geom::Point2d.new+, where the creation method
can take a variety of arguments:
Geom::Point2d.name: Point2d

Geom::Point2d#+.description:
The {#+} operator is a simple way to add to the current x and y values of the
{Geom::Point2d}, or to set the values of the {Geom::Point2d} by adding a
{Geom::Vector2d} to the {Geom::Point2d}.

Geom::Point2d#-.description:
The {#-} operator is a simple way to subtract from the current x and y values
of the {Geom::Point2d}.

Geom::Point2d#==.description:
The {#==} method compares two points for equality. This uses the standard
SketchUp tolerance to determine if two points are the same.

Geom::Point2d#[].description:
The {#[]} method returns the value of the {Geom::Point2d} at the specified
index.
parameters:
The index for a specific x or y value in the
{Geom::Point2d}
return: The new x or y value if successful

Geom::Point2d#[]=.description:
The {#[]=} method sets the x or y value of the {Geom::Point2d} based on the
specific index of the value.
parameters:
The index for a specific x or y value in the
{Geom::Point2d} to set
The value to set for x or y
return: The new x or y value if successful

Geom::Point2d#clone.description:
The {#clone} method creates another point identical to the {Geom::Point2d}
being cloned.
Geom::Point2d#clone.name: clone

Geom::Point2d#distance.description:
The {#distance} method computes the distance from the {Geom::Point2d} to
another {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#distance.name: distance
return: the distance between the points in the current units

Geom::Point2d#inspect.description: The {#inspect} method formats the {Geom::Point2d} as a string.
Geom::Point2d#inspect.name: inspect

Geom::Point2d#offset.description:
The {#offset} method offsets the {Geom::Point2d} by a {Geom::Vector2d} and
returns a new {Geom::Point2d}. If distance is provided, it must be non-zero.
Geom::Point2d#offset.name: offset

Geom::Point2d#offset!.description:
The {#offset!} method offsets the {Geom::Point2d} by a {Geom::Vector2d}.
The {Geom::Point2d} itself is modified. The length of the vector must not be
zero.
Geom::Point2d#offset!.name: offset!

Geom::Point2d#set!.description: The {#set!} method sets the values of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#set!.name: set!

Geom::Point2d#to_a.description: The {#to_a} method converts the {Geom::Point2d} to an array of 2 numbers.
Geom::Point2d#to_a.name: to_a
return:
an array of two numbers representing x, y
of the {Geom::Point2d}

Geom::Point2d#to_s.description: The {#to_s} method returns a string representation of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#to_s.name: to_s

Geom::Point2d#transform.description:
The {#transform} method applies a transformation to a point, returning a new
point. The original point is unchanged by this method.
Geom::Point2d#transform.name: transform
parameters: A Transformation object to apply to the point.

Geom::Point2d#transform!.description:
The {#transform!} method applies a transformation to a point. The point
itself is modified.
Geom::Point2d#transform!.name: transform!
parameters: A Transformation object to apply to the point.

Geom::Point2d#vector_to.description: The {#vector_to} method returns the vector between points.
Geom::Point2d#vector_to.name: vector_to

Geom::Point2d#x.description: The {#x} method returns the x value of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#x.name: x

Geom::Point2d#x=.description: The {#x=} method sets the x value of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#x=.name: x=
parameters: The desired x value of the {Geom::Point2d}
return: The new x value of the {Geom::Point2d}

Geom::Point2d#y.description: The {#y} method returns the y value of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#y.name: y

Geom::Point2d#y=.description: The {#y=} method sets the y value of the {Geom::Point2d}.
Geom::Point2d#y=.name: y=
parameters: The desired y value of the {Geom::Point2d}
return: The new y value of the {Geom::Point2d}

Geom::Point3d.description:
The Point3d class allows you to work with a point in 3D space.
The point is basically just a series of values representing x, y and z
coordinates.

The values are specified as [x,y,z]. For example [100,200,300].
To create a point call Geom::Point3d.new, where the creation method
can take a variety of arguments:

In addition to the methods below, there are a series of geometry
related methods that are on the Array class, since Point3d objects
can also be represented as a 3-element Array. These Array-level methods are
for operations such as determining if a point is on a line, on a plane, etc.
See the Array class for details.
Geom::Point3d.name: Point3d

Geom::Point3d#+.description:
The {#+} operator is a fast way to add to the current x, y and z values of
a vector.

Geom::Point3d#-.description:
The '-' operator is a fast way to subtract from the current x, y and z values
of a point.

Geom::Point3d#<.description:
The '<' operator is a fast way to determine if another point is closer to the
origin.
return: true if the point2 is closer to the origin.

Geom::Point3d#==.description:
The == method is used to compare two points for equality.

This uses the standard SketchUp tolerance to determine if two points are the
same.

Points can be compared to one another or to an array representing
x, y and z coordinates, as in the following examples:
return:
true if both points are equal; false if points are not
equal

Geom::Point3d#[].description:
The [] method is used to retrieve the value of the point at the specified
index.
parameters:
The index for a specific x, y, or z value within the
Point3d.
return: an x, y, or z value if successful

Geom::Point3d#[]=.description:
The []= method is used to set the x, y, or z value of the point based on the
specific index of the value.
parameters:
The index for a specific x, y, or z value within the
Point3d.
New x, y, or z value.
return: the newly set x, y, or z value if successful

Geom::Point3d#clone.description:
The clone method is used to create another point identical to the point
being cloned.
Geom::Point3d#clone.name: clone

Geom::Point3d#distance.description:
The distance method is used to compute the distance from a point to another
point.
Geom::Point3d#distance.name: distance
parameters: The Point3d object to compute the distance to.

Geom::Point3d#distance_to_line.description:
The distance_to_line method is used to compute the distance from a point to
a line.

See Geom module for how to specify a line.
Geom::Point3d#distance_to_line.name: distance_to_line
parameters: A line (see Geom for information on creating lines).
return:
the distance between a point and line in
internal units if successful

Geom::Point3d#distance_to_plane.description:
The distance_to_plane method is used to compute the distance from the point
to a plane.

See module Geom for how to specify a plane.
Geom::Point3d#distance_to_plane.name: distance_to_plane
parameters: A plane (see Geom for how to create a plane).
return:
a distance between a point and a plane in
internal units if successful

Geom::Point3d#initialize.description: The new method is used to create a new 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::Point3d#inspect.description:
The inspect method is used to format a 3D point as a string.

You will not often use these function directly. Instead, they are called
automatically when an object is output using a print command like 'puts',
which writes to the Ruby console.
Geom::Point3d#inspect.name: inspect

Geom::Point3d#offset.description:
The offset method is used to offset a point by a vector and return a new
point. The length of the vector must not be zero.
Geom::Point3d#offset.name: offset
parameters: A Vector3d object to offset the point by.

the distance to offset. If not provided, the
offset is my a distance equal to the vector length.

Geom::Point3d#offset!.description:
The offset! method is used to offset a point by a vector. The point itself
is modified.

Unlike offset, the point itself is modified.
Geom::Point3d#offset!.name: offset!
parameters: A Vector3d object to offset the point by.

the distance to offset. If not provided, the
offset is my a distance equal to the vector length.

Geom::Point3d#on_line?.description:
The on_line? method is used to determine if the point is on a line.

See module Geom for the various ways to specify a line.
Geom::Point3d#on_line?.name: on_line?
parameters: A line (see Geom for how to create a line).

Geom::Point3d#on_plane?.description:
The on_plane? method is used to determine if the point is on a plane.

See module Geom for the various ways to specify a plane.
Geom::Point3d#on_plane?.name: on_plane?

Geom::Point3d#project_to_line.description:
The project_to_line method is used to retrieve the point on a line that is
closest to this point.

The line may be defined by either a point and a vector or by two points.
Geom::Point3d#project_to_line.name: project_to_line
parameters: see Geom for how to specify a line
return:
the Point3d that is on a line closest to the
point

Geom::Point3d#project_to_plane.description:
The project_to_plane method is used to retrieve the point on a plane that is
closest to the point.

The plane may be defined by either a point on the plane and a vector
perpendicular to the plane or by the coeficients to the plane equation AX +
BY + CZ + D = 0. See Geom for details.
Geom::Point3d#project_to_plane.name: project_to_plane
parameters: A plane (see Geom for how to create a plane).
return:
the Point3d that is on a plane closest to the
point

Geom::Point3d#set!.description: The {#set!} method is used to set the values of the Point3d.
Geom::Point3d#set!.name: set!

Geom::Point3d#to_a.description: The to_a method is used to convert the point to an array of 3 numbers
Geom::Point3d#to_a.name: to_a
return:
an array of three numbers representing x,y,z of
the Point3d

Geom::Point3d#to_s.description: The to_s method is used to retrieve a string representation of a point.
Geom::Point3d#to_s.name: to_s
return: the string representation of the Point3d

Geom::Point3d#transform.description:
Apply a Transformation to a point, returning a new point. The original
vector is unchanged by this method.
Geom::Point3d#transform.name: transform

Geom::Point3d#transform!.description: Apply a Transformation to a point. The point itself is modified.
Geom::Point3d#transform!.name: transform!

Geom::Point3d#vector_to.description: The vector_to team method retrieves the vector between points.
Geom::Point3d#vector_to.name: vector_to

Geom::Point3d#x.description: The x method retrieves the x value of the 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#x.name: x

Geom::Point3d#x=.description: The x= method is used to set the x value of a 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#x=.name: x=

Geom::Point3d#y.description: The y method retrieves the y value of the 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#y.name: y

Geom::Point3d#y=.description: The y= method is used to set the y value of a 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#y=.name: y=

Geom::Point3d#z.description: The z method retrieves the z value of the 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#z.name: z

Geom::Point3d#z=.description: The z= method is used to set the z value of a 3D point.
Geom::Point3d#z=.name: z=

Geom::Point3d.linear_combination.description:
The {.linear_combination} method is used to create a new point as a linear
combination of two points.

This method is generally used to get a point at
some percentage along a line connecting the two points.

A linear combination is a standard term for vector math. It is defined as
point = weight1 * point1 + weight2 * point2.
Geom::Point3d.linear_combination.name: linear_combination

Geom::PolygonMesh.description:
The {#Geom::PolygonMesh} class contains methods to create polygon mesh
structures. This is useful if you need to write a custom importer/exporter in
Ruby that works at the level of triangulated polygons. For example, you can
determine the triangles that make up a 15-sided {#Sketchup::Face} by using
this class, or write a {#Sketchup::Importer} that reads a data file, creates
a mesh from it, and draws faces based on the mesh.

You can construct a mesh manually using the methods of this class, or you
can get a mesh from a face by calling the Face.mesh method. See
{Sketchup::Entities#add_faces_from_mesh} for an easy way to convert a mesh
back into faces.
Geom::PolygonMesh.name: PolygonMesh

Geom::PolygonMesh#add_point.description:
The {#add_point} method is used to add a point to the mesh.

The index can be used for creating polygons.
Geom::PolygonMesh#add_point.name: add_point
return: the index in the mesh for the point

Geom::PolygonMesh#add_polygon.description:
The +add_polygon+ method is used for adding a polygon to a
PolygonMesh. All variations of this method require at least 3 elements
to define a polygon, although more may be given.
Geom::PolygonMesh#add_polygon.name: add_polygon
return: The index of the polygon in the mesh.

Geom::PolygonMesh#count_points.description: The {#count_points} method is used to count the number of points in a mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#count_points.name: count_points
return: the number of points in a mesh

Geom::PolygonMesh#count_polygons.description: The {#count_polygons} count the number of polygons in the mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#count_polygons.name: count_polygons
return: the number of polygons in the mesh

Geom::PolygonMesh#initialize.description:
Create a new empty polygon mesh. The number of points and polygons are
optional and are just used as a hint to decide how much space to
pre-allocate to speed up adding points and polygons.
Geom::PolygonMesh#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::PolygonMesh#normal_at.description:
The {#normal_at} method is used to determine the vertex normal at a
particular index in the mesh. This only works for meshes retrieved from
{Sketchup::Face#mesh} with the +PolygonMeshNormals+ flag.
Geom::PolygonMesh#normal_at.name: normal_at
parameters:
The index in the mesh for the vertex normal to be
retrieved

Geom::PolygonMesh#point_at.description:
The {#point_at} method is used to retrieve the point at a specific index in
the mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#point_at.name: point_at
parameters: The index in the mesh for the point to be retrieved

Geom::PolygonMesh#point_index.description:
The {#point_index} method is used to retrieve the index of a point in the
mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#point_index.name: point_index
return: the index in the mesh for the {Geom::Point3d} object

Geom::PolygonMesh#points.description:
The {#points} method is used to retrieve an array of points (vertices) in the
mesh
Geom::PolygonMesh#points.name: points

Geom::PolygonMesh#polygon_at.description:
The {#polygon_at} method is used to retrieve an array of vertex index values
for a polygon at a specific index.
Geom::PolygonMesh#polygon_at.name: polygon_at
parameters: The index of the desired polygon.

Geom::PolygonMesh#polygon_points_at.description:
The {#polygon_points_at} method is used to retrieve the points for a polygon
that is at a specific index in the mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#polygon_points_at.name: polygon_points_at
parameters: An index for a polygon in the mesh.

Geom::PolygonMesh#polygons.description:
The {#polygons} method is used to retrieve an array of all polygons in the
mesh.

The returned array contains an array that can have a negative value with the
sign indicating a hidden edge. For example, a return value of +[-1, 2, 3]+
indicates that the edge from +1+ to +2+ is hidden.
Geom::PolygonMesh#polygons.name: polygons

Geom::PolygonMesh#set_point.description:
The {#set_point} method is used to set the point at a specific index in the
mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#set_point.name: set_point
parameters: The index where the point will be set.
A Point3d object to set at the index.

Geom::PolygonMesh#set_uv.description:
The {#set_uv} method is used to define UV mapping coordinates to points in
the mesh.

Beware that the polygons connected to the point will share UV coordiates so
UV mapping coordinates needs to be continuous across the polygon mesh.

When setting the UV for a point one need to make sure to have the correct
index for the point. It's therefore best to add the points using {#add_point}
and use the index it returns for following calls to set_uv and
{#add_polygon}.

If you are not able to calculate how many points there will be in your mesh
make sure to not specify an index in {#set_uv} higher than the number of
times you have called {#set_uv}.
Geom::PolygonMesh#set_uv.name: set_uv
parameters: An Integer representing the UV index.
A Point3d object representing UV coordinates.
A boolean representing the front or back.

Geom::PolygonMesh#transform!.description: The {#transform!} method is used to apply a transformation to a mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#transform!.name: transform!

Geom::PolygonMesh#uv_at.description:
The {#uv_at} method is used to access a uv (texture coordinates) at a
specific index.

"UVs" is a way of referring to the u,v texture coordinates (as
opposed to the X, Y, and Z axis that you construct your meshes on), which
are points defining 1-by-1 positions within an image. These coordinates
connect to points in your 3D model, to position an image texture onto it's
surface (similar to virtual "thumb tacks")

These coordinates pin an exact spot on an image that you wish to use to
texture your model to a specific point on an object's surface. Between these
points, your software will stretch the image smoothly. This is what is
referred to as UV mapping.
Geom::PolygonMesh#uv_at.name: uv_at
parameters: The index for the texture coordinate.

Set to +true+ to get the UV for the front size,
+false+ for the back side.
return:
a Point3d object where the x equals the u
value and the y equals the v value.
Returns nil on failure.

Geom::PolygonMesh#uvs.description:
The {#uvs} method is used to retrieve an array of uv coordinates in the
mesh.
Geom::PolygonMesh#uvs.name: uvs

Geom::Transformation.description:
Transformations are a standard construct in the 3D world for representing
the position, rotation, and sizing of a given entity. In the SketchUp
world, {Sketchup::ComponentInstance} and {Sketchup::Group} have a
+.transformation+ method that reports their current state and various methods
(+.move!+, +transformation=+, etc.) that allow them to be manipulated.

Use of the transformation class requires a knowledge of geometrical
transformations in 3 dimensions which is covered extensively on
the Internet.
Geom::Transformation.name: Transformation

Geom::Transformation#*.description: The {#*} method is used to do matrix multiplication using the transform.

Geom::Transformation#clone.description: The {#clone} method is used to create a copy of a transformation.
Geom::Transformation#clone.name: clone

Geom::Transformation#identity?.description:
The {#identity?} method is used to determine if a transformation is the
{IDENTITY} transform.
Geom::Transformation#identity?.name: identity?
return: +true+ if the transformation is the identity

Geom::Transformation#initialize.description:
The new method is used to create a new transformation.

You can use this method or one of the more specific methods for creating
specific kinds of Transformations.
Geom::Transformation#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::Transformation#inverse.description: The {#inverse} method is used to retrieve the inverse of a transformation.
Geom::Transformation#inverse.name: inverse

Geom::Transformation#invert!.description: The {#invert!} method sets the transformation to its inverse.
Geom::Transformation#invert!.name: invert!

Geom::Transformation#origin.description: The {#origin} method retrieves the origin of a rigid transformation.
Geom::Transformation#origin.name: origin

Geom::Transformation#set!.description:
The {#set!} method is used to set this transformation to match another one.

The argument is anything that can be converted into a transformation.
Geom::Transformation#set!.name: set!

Geom::Transformation#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method retrieves a 16 element array which contains the values that
define the transformation.
Geom::Transformation#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::Transformation#xaxis.description: The {#xaxis} method retrieves the x axis of a rigid transformation.
Geom::Transformation#xaxis.name: xaxis

Geom::Transformation#yaxis.description: The {#yaxis} method retrieves the y axis of a rigid transformation.
Geom::Transformation#yaxis.name: yaxis

Geom::Transformation#zaxis.description: The {#zaxis} method retrieves the z axis of a rigid transformation.
Geom::Transformation#zaxis.name: zaxis

Geom::Transformation.axes.description:
The axes method creates a transformation that goes from world coordinates
to an arbitrary coordinate system defined by an origin and three axis
vectors.
Geom::Transformation.axes.name: axes

Geom::Transformation.interpolate.description:
The interpolate method is used to create a new transformation that is the
result of interpolating between two other transformations.

Parameter is a weight (between 0.0 and 1.0) that identifies whether to favor
transformation1 or transformation2.
Geom::Transformation.interpolate.name: interpolate

Geom::Transformation.rotation.description:
The rotation method is used to create a transformation that does rotation
about an axis.

The axis is defined by a point and a vector. The angle is given in radians.
Geom::Transformation.rotation.name: rotation

Geom::Transformation.scaling.description: The scaling method is used to create a transformation that does scaling.
Geom::Transformation.scaling.name: scaling

Geom::Transformation.translation.description:
The translation method is used to create a transformation that does
translation.
Geom::Transformation.translation.name: translation

Geom::Transformation2d#*.description: The {#*} method is used to do matrix multiplication using the transform.

Geom::Transformation2d#==.description:
The {#==} method checks to see if the two {Geom::Transformation2d}s are equal.
This checks whether the values of the transformations are the same.

Geom::Transformation2d#clone.description: The {#clone} method creates a copy of the {Geom::Transformation2d}.
Geom::Transformation2d#clone.name: clone

Geom::Transformation2d#identity?.description:
The {#identity?} method determines if the {Geom::Transformation2d} is the
{IDENTITY_2D} transform.
Geom::Transformation2d#identity?.name: identity?
return: +true+ if the transform is the identity

Geom::Transformation2d#initialize.description:
The {#initialize} method creates a new {Geom::Transformation2d}. You can use
this method or one of the more specific methods for creating specific kinds
of {Geom::Transformation2d}.
Geom::Transformation2d#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::Transformation2d#inverse.description: The {#inverse} method is used to retrieve the inverse of a transformation.
Geom::Transformation2d#inverse.name: inverse

Geom::Transformation2d#invert!.description: The {#invert!} method sets the transformation to its inverse.
Geom::Transformation2d#invert!.name: invert!

Geom::Transformation2d#set!.description:
The {#set!} method sets the {Geom::Transformation2d} to match another one.
The argument is anything that can be converted into a {Geom::Transformation2d}.
Geom::Transformation2d#set!.name: set!

Geom::Transformation2d#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method returns a 6 element array which contains the values that
define the Transformation2d.
Geom::Transformation2d#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::Transformation2d.rotation.description:
The {.rotation} method is used to create a transformation that does rotation
about a point.
Geom::Transformation2d.rotation.name: rotation

Geom::Transformation2d.scaling.description: The {.scaling} method is used to create a transformation that does scaling.
Geom::Transformation2d.scaling.name: scaling

Geom::Transformation2d.translation.description:
The {.translation} method is used to create a transformation that does
translation.
Geom::Transformation2d.translation.name: translation

Geom::UTM.description: The UTM class lets you work with UTM map coordinates.
Geom::UTM.name: UTM

Geom::UTM#initialize.name: initialize

Geom::UTM#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method returns a UTM coordinate as a 4 element array. The Array
elements are the zone number, the zone letter, the x coordinate and the y
coordinate.
Geom::UTM#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::UTM#to_latlong.description:
The {#to_latlong} method is used to convert UTM coordinates to latitude
and longitude. See the LatLong class for more information.
Geom::UTM#to_latlong.name: to_latlong

Geom::UTM#to_s.description: The {#to_s} method is used to retrieve a string representation of a UTM.
Geom::UTM#to_s.name: to_s

Geom::UTM#x.description: The {#x} method returns the UTM x coordinate.
Geom::UTM#x.name: x

Geom::UTM#y.description: The {#y} method returns the UTM y coordinate.
Geom::UTM#y.name: y

Geom::UTM#zone_letter.description: The {#zone_letter} method returns the UTM zone letter.
Geom::UTM#zone_letter.name: zone_letter

Geom::UTM#zone_number.description: The {#zone_number} method returns the UTM zone number.
Geom::UTM#zone_number.name: zone_number

Geom::Vector2d.description:
The {Geom::Vector2d} class represents vectors in a 2 dimensional space.

There are numerous tutorials on 2D vectors available on the internet.
Geom::Vector2d.name: Vector2d

Geom::Vector2d#%.description:
The {#%} method returns the dot product between two {Geom::Vector2d}. This is
an alias of the dot method.
return: The dot product of the vectors

Geom::Vector2d#*.description:
The {#*} method returns the cross product between two {Geom::Vector2d}. This
is an alias of the cross method.

Geom::Vector2d#+.description: The {#+} method adds a {Geom::Vector2d} to this one.

Geom::Vector2d#-.description: The {#-} method subtracts a {Geom::Vector2d} from this one.

Geom::Vector2d#==.description:
The {#==} method returns whether two {Geom::Vector2d} are equal within
tolerance.

Geom::Vector2d#[].description:
The {#[]} method returns the value of the {Geom::Vector2d} at the specified
index.
parameters: The index into an array of two coordinates.
return: The value for the x or y coordinate.

Geom::Vector2d#[]=.description:
The {#[]=} method sets the x or y value of the {Geom::Vector2d} based on the
specific index of the value.
parameters:
The index for a specific x or y value in the
{Geom::Vector2d} to set
The value to set for x or y
return: The new x or y value if successful

Geom::Vector2d#angle_between.description:
The {#angle_between} method computes the angle in radians between
the {Geom::Vector2d} and another {Geom::Vector2d}.
Geom::Vector2d#angle_between.name: angle_between

Geom::Vector2d#clone.description:
The {#clone} method makes a copy of the {Geom::Vector2d}. This method is
equivalent to vec2 = Geom::Vector2d.new(vec).
Geom::Vector2d#clone.name: clone

Geom::Vector2d#cross.description:
The {#*} method returns the cross product between two {Geom::Vector2d}. This
is an alias of the cross method.
Geom::Vector2d#cross.name: cross

Geom::Vector2d#dot.description:
The {#%} method returns the dot product between two {Geom::Vector2d}. This is
an alias of the dot method.
Geom::Vector2d#dot.name: dot
return: The dot product of the vectors

Geom::Vector2d#inspect.description: The {#inspect} method formats the {Geom::Vector2d} as a string.
Geom::Vector2d#inspect.name: inspect

Geom::Vector2d#length.description: The {#length} method returns the length of the {Geom::Vector2d}.
Geom::Vector2d#length.name: length

Geom::Vector2d#length=.description:
The {#length=} method sets the length of the {Geom::Vector2d}. The new length
must not be 0.
Geom::Vector2d#length=.name: length=

Geom::Vector2d#normalize.description:
The {#normalize} method returns a {Geom::Vector2d} that is a unit vector
of the {Geom::Vector2d}.
Geom::Vector2d#normalize.name: normalize

Geom::Vector2d#normalize!.description:
The {#normalize!} method converts a {Geom::Vector2d} vector into a unit
vector. Another way to do this is vector.length = 1
Geom::Vector2d#normalize!.name: normalize!

Geom::Vector2d#parallel?.description:
The {#parallel?} method determines if the {Geom::Vector2d} is parallel to
another {Geom::Vector2d} to within tolerance.
Geom::Vector2d#parallel?.name: parallel?

Geom::Vector2d#perpendicular?.description:
The {#perpendicular?} method determines if the {Geom::Vector2d} is
perpendicular to another {Geom::Vector2d} to within tolerance.
Geom::Vector2d#perpendicular?.name: perpendicular?

Geom::Vector2d#reverse.description:
The {#reverse} method returns a new {Geom::Vector2d} that is the reverse of
the {Geom::Vector2d}, leaving the original unchanged.
Geom::Vector2d#reverse.name: reverse

Geom::Vector2d#reverse!.description: The {#reverse!} method reverses the {Geom::Vector2d} in place.
Geom::Vector2d#reverse!.name: reverse!

Geom::Vector2d#same_direction?.description:
The {#same_direction?} method determines if the {Geom::Vector2d} is parallel
to and in the same direction as another {Geom::Vector2d} within tolerance.
Geom::Vector2d#same_direction?.name: same_direction?

Geom::Vector2d#set!.description: The {#set!} method sets the values of the {Geom::Vector2d}.
Geom::Vector2d#set!.name: set!

Geom::Vector2d#to_a.description:
The {#to_a} method retrieves the coordinates of the {Geom::Vector2d} in an
Array.
Geom::Vector2d#to_a.name: to_a

Geom::Vector2d#to_s.description: The {#to_s} method returns a string representation of the {Geom::Vector2d}.
Geom::Vector2d#to_s.name: to_s

Geom::Vector2d#transform.description:
The {#transform} method applies a transformation to a vector, returning a new
vector. The original vector is unchanged by this method.
Geom::Vector2d#transform.name: transform
parameters: A transformation object to apply to the vector.
