page that you transition from (+from_scene+), the scene page that you
transition to (+to_scene+), and a +percent_done+ between +0.0+ and +1.0+
that tell you the percentage of the transition between the two scene
pages.

By watching for +percent_done >= 1.0+, you can activate Ruby code that
executes as soon as the user's camera has finished animating.
Sketchup::FrameChangeObserver#frameChang.name: frameChange
parameters: The previous scene page the view is transitioning from.
The selected scene page the view is transitioning towards.
The percentage of transition between the two scene pages.
return: Value can be anything, but is ignored by SketchUp.

Sketchup::Group.description:
A Group class contains methods for manipulating groups of entities.

Groups in SketchUp are very similar to components, but can from a user point
of view be thought of as unique objects. Groups can be instanced when copied
but are silently made unique when edited through the GUI. To honor this
behavior, make sure to call {#make_unique} before modifying a group through
the API.
Sketchup::Group.name: Group

Sketchup::Group#add_observer.description:
The add_observer method is used to add a ComponentInstance observer to the
group.
Sketchup::Group#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Group#copy.description:
The copy method is used to create a new Group object that is a copy of the
group.
Sketchup::Group#copy.name: copy

Sketchup::Group#definition.description:
The definition method is used to retrieve the component definition for this
group.
Sketchup::Group#definition.name: definition

Sketchup::Group#description.description: The description method is used to retrieve the description for the group.
Sketchup::Group#description.name: description

Sketchup::Group#description=.description: The description= method is used to set the description for the group.
Sketchup::Group#description=.name: description=

Sketchup::Group#entities.description:
The entities method is used to retrieve a collection of entities in the
group.
Sketchup::Group#entities.name: entities

Sketchup::Group#equals?.description:
The equals? method is used to determine if a group is geometrically
equivalent to another group.
Sketchup::Group#equals?.name: equals?
parameters: The group to compare this group with.

Sketchup::Group#explode.description: The explode method is used to explode the group into individual entities.
Sketchup::Group#explode.name: explode
return:
An array of entity objects if successful, false if
unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Group#guid.description:
The guid method is used to get the base 64 encoded unique id
for this SketchUp object.
Sketchup::Group#guid.name: guid

Sketchup::Group#intersect.description:
The intersect method is used to compute the boolean intersection of two
groups representing manifold solid volumes (this & arg).  If the specified
objects (this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes, this method fails.
Sketchup::Group#intersect.name: intersect
parameters: The group to intersect this group with.
return:
The resultant group if the two objects
(this and arg) represent manifold solids and the
operation succeeds. Otherwise nil is returned.

Sketchup::Group#local_bounds.name: local_bounds

Sketchup::Group#locked=.description: The locked= method is used to lock a group.
Sketchup::Group#locked=.name: locked=
return: true if the group is locked, false if not

Sketchup::Group#locked?.description: The locked? method is used to determine if a group is locked.
Sketchup::Group#locked?.name: locked?

Sketchup::Group#make_unique.description:
The {#make_unique} method is used to force a group to have a unique
definition. If the group is already unique in the model, nothing happens.

Copying a group in SketchUp will create a group that shares the same
definition. SketchUp implicitly makes group unique when edited from the GUI,
and from a user point of view groups could be thought of as always being
unique. To honor this behavior, call this method before editing a group
through the API.
Sketchup::Group#make_unique.name: make_unique

Sketchup::Group#manifold?.description: The manifold? method is used to determine if a group is manifold.
Sketchup::Group#manifold?.name: manifold?

Sketchup::Group#move!.description:
The {#move!} method is used to set the transformation of this group
instance, similarly to {#transformation=} but without recording to the undo
stack.

This method is useful for moving entities inside of an animation or page
transition.
Sketchup::Group#move!.name: move!
return: the transformed Group object if successful

Sketchup::Group#name.description: The name method is used to retrieve the name of the group.
Sketchup::Group#name.name: name
return: The name of the group if successful

Sketchup::Group#name=.description: The name= method is used to set the description for the group.
Sketchup::Group#name=.name: name=

Sketchup::Group#outer_shell.description:
The outer_shell method is used to compute the outer shell of the two groups
representing manifold solid volumes (this || arg).  If the specified objects
(this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes, this method fails.
Sketchup::Group#outer_shell.name: outer_shell
parameters: The group to outer shell this group with.
return:
The resultant group if the two objects
(this and arg) represent manifold solids and the
operation succeeds otherwise nil is returned.

Sketchup::Group#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove a ComponentInstance observer
from the group.
Sketchup::Group#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Group#show_differences.description:
The show_differences method is used to determine if a group is
geometrically equivalent to another group and in addition move the non-
matching and matching geometry to new layers.

This method will move both groups to Layer0.  Geometry that is the same
in both groups will be moved to a new layer named group_name + "_same".
Geometry that is not the same will be moved to a layer named group_name +
"_diff".

If verbose is true, a list of all the geometry that is different
from one group to the other is displayed texturally in the Ruby Console.
Sketchup::Group#show_differences.name: show_differences
parameters: The group to be compared with.

A boolean flag indicating whether to display a textural
report of the found differences to the Ruby console.
return:
true if the groups are geometrically
equivalent. Otherwise false.

Sketchup::Group#split.description:
The split method is used to compute the boolean split (map overlay) of the
two groups representing manifold solid volumes (this ^ arg). If the
specified objects (this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes,
this method fails.
Sketchup::Group#split.name: split
parameters: The group to split this group with.
return:
A vector (array) of the three resultant groups
If the two objects (this and arg) represent manifold
solids and the operation succeeds otherwise nil is
returned. The 3 groups are as follows:
The intersection of volume 1 & volume 2,
the difference of volume 1 minus volume 2,
and the reverse difference of volume 2 minus volume 1.

Sketchup::Group#subtract.description:
The subtract method is used to compute the boolean difference of the two
groups representing manifold solid volumes (this - arg).  If the specified
objects (this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes, this method fails.
Sketchup::Group#subtract.name: subtract
parameters: The group to subtract this group from.
return:
The resultant group if the two objects
(this and arg) represent manifold solids and the
operation succeeds. Otherwise nil is returned.

Sketchup::Group#to_component.description:
The to_component method is used to convert the group to a component
instance.
Sketchup::Group#to_component.name: to_component

Sketchup::Group#transform!.description: The transform! method is used to apply a transformation to a group.
Sketchup::Group#transform!.name: transform!
return: a transformed group object if successful

Sketchup::Group#transformation.description:
The transformation method is used to retrieve the transformation for the
group.
Sketchup::Group#transformation.name: transformation

Sketchup::Group#transformation=.description:
The {#transformation=} method is used to set the transformation of this
group
Sketchup::Group#transformation=.name: transformation=

Sketchup::Group#trim.description:
The trim method is used to compute the (non-destructive) boolean difference
of the two groups representing manifold solid volumes (this - arg).  If
the specified objects (this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes, this
method fails.
Sketchup::Group#trim.name: trim
parameters: The group to trim this group against.
return:
The resultant group if the two objects
(this and arg) represent manifold solids and the
operation succeeds otherwise nil is returned.

Sketchup::Group#union.description:
The union method is used to compute the boolean union of the two groups
representing manifold solid volumes (this | arg).  If the specified
objects (this and arg) do not represent manifold volumes, this method fails.
Sketchup::Group#union.name: union
parameters: The group to union this group with.
return:
The resultant group if the two objects
(this and arg) represent manifold solids and the
operation succeeds. Otherwise nil is returned.

Sketchup::Group#volume.description:
The volume method is used to compute the volume of this group if and only
if this group is manifold.
Sketchup::Group#volume.name: volume
return:
If the group represents a manifold volume,
volume will be a positive value. If volume is negative,
the group is not manifold.

Sketchup::Http.description:
The {Sketchup::Http} module provides interfaces to create asynchronous HTTP
requests. This is an alternative to the Net::Http module that comes with
Ruby StdLib - which is known to have issues within SketchUp.
Sketchup::Http.name: Http

Sketchup::Http::Request.description: Http::Request objects allows you to send HTTP request to HTTP servers.
Sketchup::Http::Request.name: Request

Sketchup::Http::Request#body.description: Gets the http body that is going to be used when sending the request.
Sketchup::Http::Request#body.name: body

Sketchup::Http::Request#body=.description: Sets the http body that is going to be used when sending the request.
Sketchup::Http::Request#body=.name: body=

Sketchup::Http::Request#headers.description: Returns the http headers that are going to be used when sending the request.
Sketchup::Http::Request#headers.name: headers

Sketchup::Http::Request#headers=.description: Sets the http headers that are going to be used when sending the request.
Sketchup::Http::Request#headers=.name: headers=

Sketchup::Http::Request#initialize.description:
The new method is used to create a new Sketchup::Http::Request.

The default port is 80, to use a different port define it in the URL when
creating a new Http::Request

Keeping a reference to the request is necessary in order to ensure the use of
the response.

The +method+ parameter accepts any custom http method or one of the
following:
* +Sketchup::Http::GET+
* +Sketchup::Http::POST+
* +Sketchup::Http::PUT+
* +Sketchup::Http::DELETE+
* +Sketchup::Http::HEAD+
* +Sketchup::Http::OPTIONS+
Sketchup::Http::Request#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
Optionally, the request method to use, the
default is Sketchup::Http::GET

Sketchup::Http::Request#method.description: Returns the http method that is going to be used when sending the request.
Sketchup::Http::Request#method.name: method

Sketchup::Http::Request#method=.description:
Sets the http method that is going to be used when sending the request.
The value can be any custom http method or one of the following:
* +Sketchup::Http::GET+
* +Sketchup::Http::POST+
* +Sketchup::Http::PUT+
* +Sketchup::Http::DELETE+
* +Sketchup::Http::HEAD+
* +Sketchup::Http::OPTIONS+
Sketchup::Http::Request#method=.name: method=
parameters: A string containing the http method name.

Sketchup::Http::Request#set_download_pro.description:
Adds a download progress callback block that will get called everytime we
have received data from the server until the download finishes.
Sketchup::Http::Request#set_download_pro.name: set_download_progress_callback

Sketchup::Http::Request#set_upload_progr.description:
Adds a upload progress callback block that will get called everytime we have
uploaded data to the server until the upload finishes.
Sketchup::Http::Request#set_upload_progr.name: set_upload_progress_callback

Sketchup::Http::Request#start.description: Starts the request and optionally add a callback block.
Sketchup::Http::Request#start.name: start

Sketchup::Http::Request#status.description:
Returns the internal status code. It can be one of the following:
* +Sketchup::Http::STATUS_UNKNOWN+
* +Sketchup::Http::STATUS_SUCCESS+
* +Sketchup::Http::STATUS_PENDING+
* +Sketchup::Http::STATUS_CANCELED+
* +Sketchup::Http::STATUS_FAILED+
Sketchup::Http::Request#status.name: status

Sketchup::Http::Request#url.description: Returns a copy of the Request's URL.
Sketchup::Http::Request#url.name: url

Sketchup::Http::Response.description:
Http::Response objects allows you to get the response information from the
server, you can only receive the Http::Response if you have attached a
callback block when calling start from the Http::Request object.
Sketchup::Http::Response.name: Response

Sketchup::Http::Response#body.description:
Gets the http body that was received from the server as a string encoded
using the charset provided in the Content-Type of the server response, if
no charset is specified, ASCII-8BIT will be used.
Sketchup::Http::Response#body.name: body

Sketchup::Http::Response#headers.description: Returns the http headers that were sent by the server.
Sketchup::Http::Response#headers.name: headers

Sketchup::Http::Response#status_code.description: Returns the HTTP response status code as defined in rfc2616.
Sketchup::Http::Response#status_code.name: status_code

Sketchup::Image.description: An Image object represents a raster image placed in the Model.
Sketchup::Image.name: Image

Sketchup::Image#explode.description:
The explode method is used to explode an image into a face with a texture
on it.

Note that current versions of SketchUp will return an empty array here.
To work around this limitation you can iterate over your entities collection
to determine which new entities were created.

Versions prior to SketchUp 2015 returned an empty array due to a bug.
Sketchup::Image#explode.name: explode
return:
entitiesarray - an Array object of entities if
successful

Sketchup::Image#height.description:
The height method is used to retrieve the height of the image.

The height is given in inches.
Sketchup::Image#height.name: height
return: height - the height of the model if successful

Sketchup::Image#height=.description:
The height= method is used to set the height of the image.

The height is set in inches.
Sketchup::Image#height=.name: height=
parameters: The height, in inches, to set the image.
return: height - the new height if successful

Sketchup::Image#image_rep.description:
The {#image_rep} method returns a copy of a {Sketchup::ImageRep} object
representing the pixel data.
Sketchup::Image#image_rep.name: image_rep

Sketchup::Image#normal.description:
The normal method is used to retrieve the 3D Vector that is perpendicular to
the plane of the image.
Sketchup::Image#normal.name: normal
return: vector - a Vector3d object if successful

Sketchup::Image#origin.description:
The origin method is used to retrieve the 3D point that defines the origin
of the image.
Sketchup::Image#origin.name: origin
return:
point - a Point3d object containing the origin location
if successful

Sketchup::Image#origin=.description: The origin= method is used to set the 3D point as the origin of the image.
Sketchup::Image#origin=.name: origin=
parameters: A Point3d object with the new origin.
return:
point - the Point3d object representing the newly
established origin if successful

Sketchup::Image#path.description: The path method is used to retrieve the path of the file defining the image.
Sketchup::Image#path.name: path
return: path - the path for the image file if successful

Sketchup::Image#pixelheight.description:
The pixelheight method is used to retrieve the height of the image file in
pixels.
Sketchup::Image#pixelheight.name: pixelheight
return:
height - the height of the image in pixels if
successful

Sketchup::Image#pixelwidth.description:
The pixelwidth method is used to retrieve the width of the image file in
pixels.
Sketchup::Image#pixelwidth.name: pixelwidth
return: width - the width of the image in pixels if successful

Sketchup::Image#size=.description: The size= method is used to set the width and height of the image, in inches.
Sketchup::Image#size=.name: size=
return:
size - the new width and height of the image if
successful

Sketchup::Image#transform!.description: The transform! method is used to apply a transformation to the image.
Sketchup::Image#transform!.name: transform!
return: image - the transformed Image object if successful

Sketchup::Image#transformation.description:
The transformation method is used to retrieve the transformation for the
image.
Sketchup::Image#transformation.name: transformation
return: transformation - a Transformation object if successful

Sketchup::Image#transformation=.description:
The transformation= method is used to set the transformation for the
image.
Sketchup::Image#transformation=.name: transformation=

Sketchup::Image#width.description:
The width method is used to retrieve the width of the image.

The width is given in inches.
Sketchup::Image#width.name: width
return: width - the width of the image if successful

Sketchup::Image#width=.description:
The width= method is used to set the width of the image.

The width is set in inches.
Sketchup::Image#width=.name: width=
parameters: The width, in inches, to set the image.
return: width - the new width if successful

Sketchup::Image#zrotation.description:
The zrotation method is used to get the angle that the image is rotated
about the normal vector from an arbitrary X axis.
Sketchup::Image#zrotation.name: zrotation
return: vector - a Vector3d object if successful

Sketchup::ImageRep#bits_per_pixel.description:
The {#bits_per_pixel} method gets the number of bits per pixel in the
image.
Sketchup::ImageRep#bits_per_pixel.name: bits_per_pixel

Sketchup::ImageRep#color_at_uv.description:
The {#color_at_uv} method returns a color corresponding to the UV texture
coordinates. +0.0, 0.0+ maps to the bottom left and +1.0, 1.0+ to the top
right of the image.
Sketchup::ImageRep#color_at_uv.name: color_at_uv
parameters:
Use bilinear texture filtering. This
interpolates the colors instead of picking
the nearest neighbor.

Sketchup::ImageRep#colors.description:
The {#colors} method returns an array of {Sketchup::Color} for each pixel in
the image.
Sketchup::ImageRep#colors.name: colors

Sketchup::ImageRep#data.description: The {#data} method gets the pixel data for an image in a string of bytes.
Sketchup::ImageRep#data.name: data

Sketchup::ImageRep#height.description: The {#height} method returns the height of an image.
Sketchup::ImageRep#height.name: height

Sketchup::ImageRep#initialize.description:
The {#initialize} method creates a new image object. The image object will
have no data if a path to the image is not provided.
Sketchup::ImageRep#initialize.name: initialize

Sketchup::ImageRep#load_file.description: The {#load_file} method loads image data from the specified file.
Sketchup::ImageRep#load_file.name: load_file

Sketchup::ImageRep#row_padding.description:
The {#row_padding} method returns the size of the row padding of an image
in bytes.
Sketchup::ImageRep#row_padding.name: row_padding

Sketchup::ImageRep#save_file.description:
The {#save_file} method saves an image data object to an image file
specified by a path.
Sketchup::ImageRep#save_file.name: save_file

Sketchup::ImageRep#set_data.description:
The {#set_data} method discards any existing data and sets new pixel data for
the {Sketchup::ImageRep}.
Sketchup::ImageRep#set_data.name: set_data
parameters: The width of the pixel data. Must be greater than 0.

The height of the pixel data.
Must be greater than 0.

The bits per pixel for the pixel data.
Must be either 8/24/32.

The row padding for the pixel data which is
sized in bytes. Row padding is used to pad each row with zeros so that each
scanline on the pixel data will end on the data-type boundary.

The binary string containing the pixel data
representing the new image.

Sketchup::ImageRep#size.description: The {#size} method gets the total size of the image data in bytes.
Sketchup::ImageRep#size.name: size

Sketchup::ImageRep#width.description: The {#width} method returns the width of an image.
Sketchup::ImageRep#width.name: width

Sketchup::Importer.description:
The Importer interface lets you build your own importers for SketchUp. To
use this, you create a subclass of Importer and implement all of the
methods described below. This will make your importer appear in the list
that users see under File > Import, and you can use Ruby to do all of the
work of opening the file and creating whatever you need inside SketchUp.

Here is an example of a complete script that imports a .txt file and
displays its contents in a messagebox.
Sketchup::Importer.name: Importer

Sketchup::Importer#description.description:
This method is called by SketchUp to determine the description that appears
in the File > Import dialog's pulldown list of valid importers.

Though it is common for the description to include the file extension
supported by the importer (such as "Text Importer (.txt)"), the actual
extension is defined in the file_extension method.
Sketchup::Importer#description.name: description

Sketchup::Importer#do_options.description:
This method is called by SketchUp when the user clicks on the "Options"
button inside the File > Import dialog. You can use it to gather and store
settings for your importer.

Only applicable if the importer supports options, meaning its
supports_options method returns true.
Sketchup::Importer#do_options.name: do_options

Sketchup::Importer#file_extension.description:
This method is called by SketchUp to determine a single file extension is
associated with your importer. Only files that match this extension will be
shown to the user as they browse their harddrive for things to import.

Ruby importers are only allowed to support a single extension.
Sketchup::Importer#file_extension.name: file_extension

Sketchup::Importer#id.description:
This method is called by SketchUp to determine a unique identifier for
your importer, typically something like "com.sketchup.importers.dxf".
Sketchup::Importer#id.name: id

Sketchup::Importer#load_file.description:
This method is called by SketchUp after the user has selected a file to
import. This is where you do the real work by opening the file via Ruby's
File object and processing it in whatever way you need.

You must return an integer success code to SketchUp when you are done.
These are the codes that SketchUp understands:

  - Sketchup::Importer::ImportSuccess
  - Sketchup::Importer::ImportFail
  - Sketchup::Importer::ImportCanceled - SketchUp will show a "cancelled" dialog
  - Sketchup::Importer::ImportFileNotFound - SketchUp will show a "not found" dialog
Sketchup::Importer#load_file.name: load_file
parameters: Absolute path to the file the user selected
The status of the import so far. Contains true.
return: success - an integer status code. See above.

Sketchup::Importer#supports_options?.description:
This method is called by SketchUp to determine if the "Options"
button inside the File > Import dialog should be enabled while your
importer is selected.
Sketchup::Importer#supports_options?.name: supports_options?

Sketchup::InputPoint.description:
The {Sketchup::InputPoint} class is used to pick 3d points and/or entities
that reside under the current cursor location, similar to native Line tool
and other drawing tools. Unlike {Sketchup::PickHelper},
{Sketchup::InputPoint} uses inference, i.e. "snaps" to vertices and other
entities when the cursor is close to them.

Only {Sketchup::Tool}s react to cursor location and most of these methods are
only useful in the context of a tool. For example, if you want to determine
the 3d point you just moved the cursor over, you would use
{#pick} from within your {Sketchup::Tool#onMouseMove} method.
{Sketchup::InputPoints} are best picked from mouse move, as you want them to
draw them to the view.

For an example, see https://github.com/SketchUp/sketchup-ruby-api-tutorials/tree/master/examples/02_custom_tool.

To lock inference similar to native SketchUp tools, see
{View#lock_inference}.
Sketchup::InputPoint.name: InputPoint

Sketchup::InputPoint#==.description: The == method is used to determine if two input points are the same.
parameters: The second input point in the comparison.
return:
status - true if the InputPoint objects are the same
object. False if the objects are not the same.

Sketchup::InputPoint#clear.description:
The clear method is used to clear the input point.

This sets it to an empty state. After calling this, valid? will return
false.
Sketchup::InputPoint#clear.name: clear
return:
inputpoint - the cleared (empty) input point if this
successful

Sketchup::InputPoint#copy!.description:
The copy! method is used to copy the data from a second input point into
this input point.
Sketchup::InputPoint#copy!.name: copy!
return:
inputpoint - the new input point that received the copy
if successful

Sketchup::InputPoint#degrees_of_freedom.description:
The degrees_of_freedom method retrieves the number of degrees of freedom
there are for an input point.

If you are just getting a point in space, then the degrees_of_freedom will
be 3 - meaning that there is nothing about the point that would constrain
its position.

If you are on a face, then the degrees_of_freedom will be 2
meaning that you can only move on the plane of the face.

If you are on an Edge or an axis, then the degrees_of_freedom will be 1
meaning that you can only move in the direction of the edge or axis.

If you get an end point of an Edge, or an intersection point, then the
degrees_of_freedom will be 0.
Sketchup::InputPoint#degrees_of_freedom.name: degrees_of_freedom

Sketchup::InputPoint#depth.description:
The depth method retrieves the depth of an inference if it is coming from a
component.

If the InputPoint is not getting a position from inside a component, this
method will return 0. Otherwise it returns the depth of the entity in a
nested component that is providing the position.
Sketchup::InputPoint#depth.name: depth
return:
depth - a number representing the depth of the
inputpoint (inside groups and components) if successful

Sketchup::InputPoint#display?.description:
The display? method is used to determine if the input point has anything to
draw.

If the method returns true, then the draw method will draw something.
Sketchup::InputPoint#display?.name: display?
return:
status - true if the draw method will draw something,
false if the draw method has nothing to draw

Sketchup::InputPoint#draw.description:
The draw method is used to draw the input point.

This is useful for showing an InputPoint from within the draw method of a
tool that you have implemented in Ruby. Additional examples are available in
the Plugins/examples directory.
Sketchup::InputPoint#draw.name: draw

Sketchup::InputPoint#edge.description:
The edge method is used to retrieve the edge if the input point is getting
its position from a point on an Edge.
Sketchup::InputPoint#edge.name: edge
return:
edge - an Edge object if successful, or nil if
unsuccessful

Sketchup::InputPoint#face.description:
The face method retrieves the face at or behind the input point. This can be
used to determine a plane, similar to what native Rotate tool does.
Sketchup::InputPoint#face.name: face

Sketchup::InputPoint#initialize.description: The new method is used to create a new InputPoint object.
Sketchup::InputPoint#initialize.name: initialize

Sketchup::InputPoint#instance_path.description:
The {#instance_path} method retrieves the instance path for the picked point.

The returned instance_path is a copy of what the input point is holding on to
at the moment you access it. Your copy will not update if you make new picks
with the input point.

If there has been no valid pick it will return `nil`.
Sketchup::InputPoint#instance_path.name: instance_path

Sketchup::InputPoint#pick.description:
The pick method is used to get the input point at a specific screen
position.

The first form just uses the screen position to compute the InputPoint. It
is used when you don't want the InputPoint to be dependent on another
InputPoint.

The second form uses the screen position and another InputPoint. It will
find additional inferences such as along one of the axis directions from the
first point.
Sketchup::InputPoint#pick.name: pick
parameters:
A second input point used as a reference
for the pick.
return:
status - true if a valid InputPoint was picked and it
is different than it was before.

Sketchup::InputPoint#position.description: The position method is used to get the 3D point from the input point.
Sketchup::InputPoint#position.name: position
return:
point - a Point3d object position for the input point
if successful

Sketchup::InputPoint#tooltip.description:
The tooltip method is used to retrieve the string that is the tool tip to
display for the input point.
Sketchup::InputPoint#tooltip.name: tooltip
return:
tip - a string tooltip or an empty string (if the input
point doesn't provide a tooltip).

Sketchup::InputPoint#transformation.description:
The transformation method retrieves the Transformation object for the input
point.

If the InputPoint object is getting its position from something inside of a
component instance, this method returns the Transformation of the component
instance. Otherwise it returns the identity Transformation.

Note that the position method on a input point always returns a point that is
transformed into model space. If you are using the edge, face or vertex
method on the InputPoint though, you will probably need to use the
transformation method to transform the data that you get back from the
selected entity.
Sketchup::InputPoint#transformation.name: transformation
return:
transformation - the Transformation for the input point
if successful

Sketchup::InputPoint#valid?.description:
The valid? method is used to determine if an input point has valid data.

You must have called the pick method to set the data before it is valid.
Sketchup::InputPoint#valid?.name: valid?
return:
status - true if the input point has valid data, false
if it does not have valid data.

Sketchup::InputPoint#vertex.description:
The vertex method returns a Vertex associated with the InputPoint. If the
InputPoint is on the end of a line, then it will return the Vertex. If the
InputPoint does not select any vertices this method returns nil.
Sketchup::InputPoint#vertex.name: vertex

Sketchup::InstanceObserver.description:
This observer interface is implemented to react to component instance
events.

Note that you may also attach {Sketchup::InstanceObserver}s to
{Sketchup::Group}s.
Sketchup::InstanceObserver.name: InstanceObserver

Sketchup::InstanceObserver#onClose.description:
The {#onClose} method is called when an instance is "closed," meaning an end
user was editing a component's geometry and then exited back into the
parent's editing space.
Sketchup::InstanceObserver#onClose.name: onClose
parameters:
The instance that was just
closed

Sketchup::InstanceObserver#onOpen.description:
The {#onOpen} method is called when an instance is "opened," meaning an end
user has double clicked on it to edit its geometry. This is particularly
useful if your plugin is dynamically drawing geometry or performing
transformations in global space, since when in "edit component" mode all
transformations and positions are returned in relation to the current
component's origin.

This method will tell you when a user has entered edit mode, and you can
then use {Sketchup::Model#active_path} and {Sketchup::Model#edit_transform}
methods to determine any corrections you need to make to your
transformations.
Sketchup::InstanceObserver#onOpen.name: onOpen

Sketchup::InstancePath.description:
The {Sketchup::InstancePath} class represent the instance path to a given
entity within the model hierarchy.
Sketchup::InstancePath.name: InstancePath

return:
`true` if the instances paths represent the same set of
entities.

Sketchup::InstancePath#[].description: The elements of an instance path can be accessed similarly to an array.

Sketchup::InstancePath#each.description: The yielded entities will start with the root and end with the leaf.
Sketchup::InstancePath#each.name: each

Sketchup::InstancePath#include?.description: Returns `true` if the instance path contain the given object.
Sketchup::InstancePath#include?.name: include?

Sketchup::InstancePath#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
The leaf can be any entity, but the
rest must be a group or component instance.

Sketchup::InstancePath#leaf.description:
The leaf of an instance path is the last element which can be any entity
that can be represented in the model. This is normally a
{Sketchup::Drawingelement}, but could be a {Sketchup::Vertex}.

An instance can also be a leaf.
Sketchup::InstancePath#leaf.name: leaf

Sketchup::InstancePath#persistent_id_pat.description:
The serialized version of an instance path is the persistent ids of its
entities concatenated with a period.
Sketchup::InstancePath#persistent_id_pat.name: persistent_id_path

Sketchup::InstancePath#root.description:
The root of an instance path is the element located closest to the model
root. This will be a group or component instance. If you have a non-instance
as a leaf with no other parent component this will return `nil`.
Sketchup::InstancePath#root.name: root

Sketchup::InstancePath#to_a.name: to_a
return: an array representing the instance path.

Sketchup::InstancePath#valid?.description:
An instance path is valid if it has at least one element and consist of
groups and instances with exception of the leaf which can be any entity.

This method doesn't check if the path can actually be looked up in the model.
Sketchup::InstancePath#valid?.name: valid?

Sketchup::Layer.description:
The Layer class contains methods modifying and extracting information for a
layer.

By default, a SketchUp model has one layer, Layer 0 (Named "Untagged" in the
UI since SketchUp 2020), which is the base
layer. You can't delete or rename Layer 0. Unlike certain other CAD software
packages, entities associated with different layers in SketchUp still
intersect with each other. (If you want collections of entities to not
intersect, place them in Groups instead.)

Layers are commonly used to organize your model and control the visibility
of related groups and components. For example, you could make all of your
wall and roof entities different groups, associate layers with those groups,
and then hide those layers so as to display just the floor plan in the model.
Sketchup::Layer.name: Layer

Sketchup::Layer#<=>.description:
The {#<=>} method is used to compare two layers based on their names. You
could use this for sorting if you're building a list of layer names.
return:
-1 if layer1 is less than layer2. 1 if layer2
is less than layer1. 0 if layer1 and layer2 are equal.

Sketchup::Layer#==.description: The {#==} method is used to determine if two layers are the same.

Sketchup::Layer#color.description: The {#color} method is used to retrieve the color of the layer.
Sketchup::Layer#color.name: color

Sketchup::Layer#color=.description: The {#color=} method is used to set the name of a layer.
Sketchup::Layer#color=.name: color=

Sketchup::Layer#display_name.description: The {#display_name} method is used to retrieve the display name of the layer.
Sketchup::Layer#display_name.name: display_name

Sketchup::Layer#folder.description: The {#folder} method is used to return the parent layer folder of a layer.
Sketchup::Layer#folder.name: folder
return:
+nil+ if the folder is a direct child to
the layer manager.

Sketchup::Layer#folder=.description:
The {#folder=} method is used to set the parent layer folder of a layer.

This will trigger +onParentFolderChanged+ in normal cases and
+onLayerChanged+ during undo/redo.
Sketchup::Layer#folder=.name: folder=
parameters:
+nil+ will make the layer a
direct child to the layer manager.

Sketchup::Layer#line_style.description: The {#line_style} method retrieves the line style on this layer.
Sketchup::Layer#line_style.name: line_style

Sketchup::Layer#line_style=.description: The {#line_style=} method lets you set a specific line style to a layer
Sketchup::Layer#line_style=.name: line_style=
parameters: The line style to set on this layer.
return: The layer that the line style was applied on.

Sketchup::Layer#name.description: The {#name} method is used to retrieve the name of the layer.
Sketchup::Layer#name.name: name

Sketchup::Layer#name=.description: The {#name=} method is used to set the name of a layer.
Sketchup::Layer#name=.name: name=

Sketchup::Layer#page_behavior.description:
The {#page_behavior} method is used to retrieve the visibility behavior of the
layer for new pages and existing pages. For example, you may want your layer
to be visible or hidden by default in any new pages (aka Scenes) created by
the user.

A page keeps a list of layers that do not have their default behavior.
If a layer is not in that list, then it is set to its default visibility
determined by one of these values:

The behaviour is composed of a combination of these flags:

[Default visibility]
  These flags are used to set the value of {#page_behavior}. A page keeps
  a list of layers that do not have their default behavior. If a layer
  is not in that list, then it is set to its default visibility which
  is determined by one of these flags.
  - {LAYER_VISIBLE_BY_DEFAULT}: +0x0000+
  - {LAYER_HIDDEN_BY_DEFAULT}: +0x0001+

[Visibility on new pages]
  You can also set this addition flag that controls the visibility of
  a layer on newly created pages.
  - {LAYER_USES_DEFAULT_VISIBILITY_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0000+
  - {LAYER_IS_VISIBLE_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0010+
  - {LAYER_IS_HIDDEN_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0020+

The default visibility for a layer is set by either
{LAYER_VISIBLE_BY_DEFAULT} or
{LAYER_HIDDEN_BY_DEFAULT}. This is what will be used when a page
does not contain the visibility state of a layer.

The remaining flags control the visibility of the layer for new pages.
Sketchup::Layer#page_behavior.name: page_behavior
return: an integer representing the current behavior of the layer.

Sketchup::Layer#page_behavior=.description:
The {#page_behavior=} method is used to control the layer's visibility
behavior on existing and new pages.

When you Update a page (as opposed to creating a new page) the current
visibility of the layer is used.

The behavior is composed of a combination of these flags:

[Default visibility]
  These flags are used to set the value of {#page_behavior}. A page keeps
  a list of layers that do not have their default behavior. If a layer
  is not in that list, then it is set to its default visibility which
  is determined by one of these flags.
  - {LAYER_VISIBLE_BY_DEFAULT}: +0x0000+
  - {LAYER_HIDDEN_BY_DEFAULT}: +0x0001+

[Visibility on new pages]
  You can also set this addition flag that controls the visibility of
  a layer on newly created pages.
  - {LAYER_USES_DEFAULT_VISIBILITY_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0000+
  - {LAYER_IS_VISIBLE_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0010+
  - {LAYER_IS_HIDDEN_ON_NEW_PAGES}: +0x0020+
Sketchup::Layer#page_behavior=.name: page_behavior=

Sketchup::Layer#visible=.description: The {#visible=} method is used to set if the layer is visible.
Sketchup::Layer#visible=.name: visible=

Sketchup::Layer#visible?.description: The {#visible?} method is used to determine if the layer is visible.
Sketchup::Layer#visible?.name: visible?

Sketchup::LayerFolder.description: Allows layers to be organized in folders. Folders may have duplicate names.
Sketchup::LayerFolder.name: LayerFolder

Sketchup::LayerFolder#<=>.description:
The {#<=>} method is used to compare two layer folders based on their names.
You could use this for sorting if you're building a list of folder names.
return:
+-1+ if the receiver should appear before +other+.
+1+ if the receiver should appear after +other+.
+0+ if the receiver and +other+ are equal.
+nil+ if +other+ is not comparable with the receiver.

Sketchup::LayerFolder#==.description: The {#==} method is used to determine if two layer folders are the same.

Sketchup::LayerFolder#add_folder.description: The {#add_folder} method adds or moves a layer folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#add_folder.name: add_folder

Sketchup::LayerFolder#add_layer.description: The {#add_layer} method adds a layer to a folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#add_layer.name: add_layer

Sketchup::LayerFolder#count_folders.description:
The {#count_folders} method retrieves the number of child folders in the
folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#count_folders.name: count_folders

Sketchup::LayerFolder#count_layers.description: The {#count_layers} method retrieves the number of layers in the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#count_layers.name: size

Sketchup::LayerFolder#length.description: The {#count_layers} method retrieves the number of layers in the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#length.name: length

Sketchup::LayerFolder#size.description: The {#count_layers} method retrieves the number of layers in the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#size.name: size

Sketchup::LayerFolder#display_name.description: The {#name} method gets the name of the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#display_name.name: display_name

Sketchup::LayerFolder#each.description:
The {#each_layer} method is used to iterate through the layers that are
direct children to the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#each.name: each

Sketchup::LayerFolder#each_folder.description:
The {#each_folder} method is used to iterate through the folders that are
direct children to the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#each_folder.name: each_folder

Sketchup::LayerFolder#each_layer.description:
The {#each_layer} method is used to iterate through the layers that are
direct children to the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#each_layer.name: each

Sketchup::LayerFolder#folder.description:
The {#folder} method is used to return the parent layer folder of a layer
folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#folder.name: folder
return:
+nil+ if the folder is a direct child to
the layer manager.

Sketchup::LayerFolder#folder=.description:
The {#folder=} method is used to set the parent layer folder of a layer
folder.

This will trigger +onLayerFolderRemoved+ followed by +onLayerFolderAdded+.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#folder=.name: folder=
parameters:
+nil+ will make the the folder a
direct child to the layer manager.

Sketchup::LayerFolder#folders.description: The {#folders} returns the direct child-folders of the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#folders.name: folders

Sketchup::LayerFolder#layers.description: The {#layers} method retrieves the child layers of a folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#layers.name: layers

Sketchup::LayerFolder#name.description: The {#name} method gets the name of the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#name.name: display_name

Sketchup::LayerFolder#name=.description: The {#name=} method sets the name of the folder.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#name=.name: name=

Sketchup::LayerFolder#remove_folder.description:
The {#remove_folder} method removes the folder from the model. All children
are preserved, but move up one level.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#remove_folder.name: remove_folder

Sketchup::LayerFolder#remove_layer.description:
The {#remove_layer} method removes a layer from a folder. The layer will be
parent to the layer manager.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#remove_layer.name: remove_layer

Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible=.description: The {#visible=} method is used to set if the layer folder is visible.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible=.name: visible=

Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible?.description: The {#visible?} method is used to determine if the layer folder is visible.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible?.name: visible?

Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible_on_new_pag.description:
The {#visible_on_new_pages=} method is used to set if the layer folder is by
default visible on new pages.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible_on_new_pag.name: visible_on_new_pages=

Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible_on_new_pag.description:
The {#visible_on_new_pages?} method is used to determine if the layer folder
is by default visible on new pages.
Sketchup::LayerFolder#visible_on_new_pag.name: visible_on_new_pages?

Sketchup::Layers.description:
The Layers collection allows you to see and manage all of the layers in a
model. You get a pointer to the Layers object from within the Model.
Sketchup::Layers.name: Layers

Sketchup::Layers#[].description: The {#[]} method is used to retrieve a layer by index or name.
parameters:
A number representing the layer's
index in an array of Layer objects, or the name of the layer.

Sketchup::Layers#add.description:
The {#add} method is used to add a new layer.

If you give the name of a Layer that is already defined, it will return the
existing Layer rather than adding a new one.
Sketchup::Layers#add.name: add_layer
parameters: The name of the added layer.

Sketchup::Layers#add_layer.description:
The {#add} method is used to add a new layer.

If you give the name of a Layer that is already defined, it will return the
existing Layer rather than adding a new one.
Sketchup::Layers#add_layer.name: add_layer
parameters: The name of the added layer.

Sketchup::Layers#add_folder.description: The {#add_folder} method adds or moves a layer folder.
Sketchup::Layers#add_folder.name: add_folder

Sketchup::Layers#add_observer.description:
The {#add_observer} method is used to add an observer to the layers
collection.
Sketchup::Layers#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Layers#at.description: The {#at} method is an alias for {#[]}.
Sketchup::Layers#at.name: at

Sketchup::Layers#count.name: count
return: integer - the number of layers in the collection

Sketchup::Layers#count_folders.description:
The {#count_folders} method counts the number of folders which are direct
children of the layer manager.
Sketchup::Layers#count_folders.name: count_folders

Sketchup::Layers#count_layers.description: The {#count_layers} method retrieves the number of layers not in a folder.
Sketchup::Layers#count_layers.name: count_layers

Sketchup::Layers#each.description:
The {#each} method is used to iterate through all of the layers in the model.
This include layers that are nested inside folders.
Sketchup::Layers#each.name: each

Sketchup::Layers#each_folder.description:
The {#each_folder} method is used to iterate through the folders that are
direct children to the layer manager.
Sketchup::Layers#each_folder.name: each_folder

Sketchup::Layers#each_layer.description:
The {#each_layer} method is used to iterate through the layers that are not
inside a layer folder.
Sketchup::Layers#each_layer.name: each_layer

Sketchup::Layers#folders.description: The {#folders} method returns the folders of the layer manager.
Sketchup::Layers#folders.name: folders

Sketchup::Layers#layers.description: The {#layers} method retrieves the layers not in a folder.
Sketchup::Layers#layers.name: layers

Sketchup::Layers#length.description: The {#length} method retrieves the number of layers.
Sketchup::Layers#length.name: length

Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused.description: The {#purge_unused} method is used to remove unused layers.
Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused.name: purge_unused_layers

Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused_layers.description: The {#purge_unused} method is used to remove unused layers.
Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused_layers.name: purge_unused_layers

Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused_folders.description:
The {#purge_unused_folders} method is used to remove all layer folder with
no children.
Sketchup::Layers#purge_unused_folders.name: purge_unused_folders

Sketchup::Layers#remove.description: Remove the given layer from the model, optionally removing the geometry.
Sketchup::Layers#remove.name: remove_layer
parameters:
If true, geometry in the removed layer will
be removed as well. If false (which is the default),
this geometry will be placed on Layer 0.
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Layers#remove_layer.description: Remove the given layer from the model, optionally removing the geometry.
Sketchup::Layers#remove_layer.name: remove_layer
parameters:
If true, geometry in the removed layer will
be removed as well. If false (which is the default),
this geometry will be placed on Layer 0.
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Layers#remove_folder.description:
The {#remove_folder} method removes the folder from the model. All children are
preserved, but moved up one level.
Sketchup::Layers#remove_folder.name: remove_folder

Sketchup::Layers#remove_observer.description:
The {#remove_observer} method is used to remove an observer from the current
object.
Sketchup::Layers#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Layers#size.description: The {#size} method is an alias of {#length}.
Sketchup::Layers#size.name: size

Sketchup::Layers#unique_name.description:
The {#unique_name} method can be used to get a string that will be a unique
layer name inside this collection.
Sketchup::Layers#unique_name.name: unique_name

Sketchup::LayersObserver.description: This observer interface is implemented to react to layers events.
Sketchup::LayersObserver.name: LayersObserver

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onCurrentLayerC.description:
The {#onCurrentLayerChanged} method is called when the user selects a
different active layer.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onCurrentLayerC.name: onCurrentLayerChanged

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerAdded.description: The {#onLayerAdded} method is called when a new layer is added to a model.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerAdded.name: onLayerAdded

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerChanged.description: The {#onLayerChanged} method is called when a layer is changed.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerChanged.name: onLayerChanged

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderAd.description:
The {#onLayerFolderAdded} method is called when a layer folder is added
to a model.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderAd.name: onLayerFolderAdded

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderCh.description:
The {#onLayerFolderChanged} method is called when a layer folder changes
one of its properties.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderCh.name: onLayerFolderChanged

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderRe.description:
The {#onLayerFolderRemoved} method is called when a layer folder is removed
from a model.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerFolderRe.name: onLayerFolderRemoved

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerRemoved.description: The {#onLayerRemoved} method is called when a layer is removed from a model.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onLayerRemoved.name: onLayerRemoved

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onParentFolderC.description:
The {#onParentFolderChanged} method is called when a layer changes parent
folder.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onParentFolderC.name: onParentFolderChanged

Sketchup::LayersObserver#onRemoveAllLaye.description:
The {#onRemoveAllLayers} method is called when all layer are removed from a
model.
Sketchup::LayersObserver#onRemoveAllLaye.name: onRemoveAllLayers

Sketchup::Licensing.description:
The +Sketchup::Licensing+ module contains methods for
extensions purchased from Extension Warehouse to check their licensing status.

It is advised to place these calls inside encrypted Ruby (.rbe) files. This
API is also exposed via the SketchUp C API. Extensions that already use
native code should prefer using the native API, which should be more secure
than their Ruby API counterparts.

For more details, see:
{Developer Center Licensing Tutorial}[https://extensions.sketchup.com/en/developer_center/tutorial_licensing]
Sketchup::Licensing.name: Licensing

Sketchup::Licensing.get_extension_licens.description: Acquires a license for a given extension.
Sketchup::Licensing.get_extension_licens.name: get_extension_license
parameters: The Extension Warehouse UUID for the desired extension.
return:
An object representing
licensing state for the extension. Do not store this object, retrieve
it again when needed since licensing state may have changed.

Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense.description:
The Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense class is used to store extension
license information. An instance of this class is returned by
Sketchup::Licensing.get_extension_license. Note that this is a temporary
object representing the extension licensing state for the moment it was
returned. It will not reflect any licensing state changes that may occur.
Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense.name: ExtensionLicense

Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#da.description:
The days_remaining method is used to get the number of days remaining until
license expiration.
Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#da.name: days_remaining
return:
Integer - Number of days until license expiration. Zero
if a permanent license or not licensed.

Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#er.description:
The error_description method is used to obtain error information in case of
failure to acquire a license. This is meant to aid in debugging only.
Extensions should not rely on any exact error description.
Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#er.name: error_description

Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#li.description:
The licensed? method is used to decide whether the extension is licensed to
run or not.
Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#li.name: licensed?
return:
Boolean - true if the extension is allowed to run, false
if it is not licensed and should quit.

Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#st.description:
The state method returns a constant indicating the specific licensing state.
These should be used for informational purposes only and not to decide if
the extension is licensed to run. For that, please use the licensed? method.
Sketchup::Licensing::ExtensionLicense#st.name: state
return:
Integer - One of Sketchup::Licensing::LICENSED,
Sketchup::Licensing::EXPIRED, Sketchup::Licensing::TRIAL,
Sketchup::Licensing::TRIAL_EXPIRED,
Sketchup::Licensing::NOT_LICENSED

Sketchup::LineStyle.description:
This provides a way for SketchUp to customize a line style and be set on a
layer.
Sketchup::LineStyle.name: LineStyle

Sketchup::LineStyle#name.description: The {#name} method retrieves the name of the line style object.
Sketchup::LineStyle#name.name: name
return: The name of the line style.

Sketchup::LineStyles.description: Provides access to the different line style objects in the model.
Sketchup::LineStyles.name: LineStyles

Sketchup::LineStyles#[].description:
The {#[]} method lets you retrieve a line style by name or index.

The {#at} method is an alias of {#[]}.
return:
The line style retrieved. Nil if the name
couldn't be retrived.

Sketchup::LineStyles#at.description:
The {#[]} method lets you retrieve a line style by name or index.

The {#at} method is an alias of {#[]}.
Sketchup::LineStyles#at.name: at
return:
The line style retrieved. Nil if the name
couldn't be retrived.

Sketchup::LineStyles#each.description: The {#each} method is used to iterate through all the line styles.
Sketchup::LineStyles#each.name: each

Sketchup::LineStyles#length.description: The {#size} method returns the number of line styles that SketchUp supports.
Sketchup::LineStyles#length.name: length

Sketchup::LineStyles#names.description: The {#names} method return the support line styles as strings.
Sketchup::LineStyles#names.name: names

Sketchup::LineStyles#size.description: The {#size} method returns the number of line styles that SketchUp supports.
Sketchup::LineStyles#size.name: length

Sketchup::LineStyles#to_a.description: The {#to_a} method returns an array of all the line styles.
Sketchup::LineStyles#to_a.name: to_a
return: Containing all the line style objects.

Sketchup::Loop.description:
Loop is a low level topology class that will not need to be used often. A
Loop is a chain of Edges that bound a Face.
Sketchup::Loop.name: Loop

Sketchup::Loop#convex?.description: Determine if the loop is convex.
Sketchup::Loop#convex?.name: convex?
return: status - true if convex, false if not convex.

Sketchup::Loop#edges.description: Get an array of the edges that define the loop in an ordered sequence.
Sketchup::Loop#edges.name: edges
return: edges - an array of Edge objects if successful.

Sketchup::Loop#edgeuses.description:
Get an array of the EdgeUse objects that define this loop in an ordered
sequence.
Sketchup::Loop#edgeuses.name: edgeuses
return: edgeuses - an array of EdgeUse objects if successful.

Sketchup::Loop#face.description: Get the Face object that is bounded by this loop.
Sketchup::Loop#face.name: face
return: face - a Face object if successful

Sketchup::Loop#outer?.description:
Determine if this is an outer loop. Each face has one outer loop, and will
have one loop for each hole.
Sketchup::Loop#outer?.name: outer?
return:
status - true if the loop is an outer loop, false if it
is not an outer loop.

Sketchup::Loop#vertices.description: Get an array of the vertices that define the loop in an ordered sequence.
Sketchup::Loop#vertices.name: vertices
return: vertices - an array of Vertex objects if successful.

Sketchup::Material.description:
The Material class represents a texture or color that can be applied to
Drawingelements. It is most often applied to Faces.

You can pass any object that can be used as a material to a method that
requires a material. Objects include actual materials, color, and classes
that can be converted to a color.

The following are valid (assuming the existence of a Material mat1.)
Sketchup::Material.name: Material

Sketchup::Material#<=>.description:
The <=> method is used to compare two materials based on name. The number
returned relates to the "string distance" between the names.
return:
0 if they are equal, positive number if
material1 > material2, negative if material1 < material2

Sketchup::Material#==.description: The == method is used to test if two materials are the same.
return:
true if the materials are the same, false if
they are different

Sketchup::Material#alpha.description:
The alpha method is used to get the opacity of the material.

The value will be between 0.0 and 1.0. A value of 0.0 means that the material is
completely transparent. A value of 1.0 means that the Material is completely
opaque.
Sketchup::Material#alpha.name: alpha

Sketchup::Material#alpha=.description:
The alpha= method is used to set the opacity of the material.

The value must be between 0.0 and 1.0. A value of 0.0 means that the material is
completely transparent. A value of 1.0 means that the Material is completely
opaque.
Sketchup::Material#alpha=.name: alpha=

Sketchup::Material#color.description:
The color method is used to retrieve the color of the material.

If it uses a Texture, this will return the average color.
Sketchup::Material#color.name: color

Sketchup::Material#color=.description:
The color= method is used to set the color of the material.

If the Material has a texture, then this turns it into a colorized
texture.

To reset the color of a Material with a texture, set the color
to nil.
Sketchup::Material#color=.name: color=

Sketchup::Material#colorize_deltas.description: The colorize_deltas method retrieves the HLS delta for colorized materials.
Sketchup::Material#colorize_deltas.name: colorize_deltas
return: An array of floats representing the HLS delta.

Sketchup::Material#colorize_type.description:
The colorize_type method retrieves the type of colorization of the material.
This value is only relevant when the materialType is set to 2
(colorized textured).
Types include:

  - 0 = shift (Sketchup::Material::COLORIZE_SHIFT),
  - 1 = tint (Sketchup::Material::COLORIZE_TINT),
Sketchup::Material#colorize_type.name: colorize_type
return: the colorize type for the Material object.

Sketchup::Material#colorize_type=.description:
The colorize_type method set the type of colorization of the material.
This value is only relevant when the materialType is set to 2
(colorized textured).
Types include:

  - 0 = shift (Sketchup::Material::COLORIZE_SHIFT),
  - 1 = tint (Sketchup::Material::COLORIZE_TINT),
Sketchup::Material#colorize_type=.name: colorize_type=
parameters: the new colorize type for the Material object.
return: the colorize type for the Material object.

Sketchup::Material#display_name.description:
The display_name method retrieves the name that is displayed within SketchUp
for the material.

This should be used when presenting the name in the UI, but the returned name
cannot be used as a key in model.materials.
Sketchup::Material#display_name.name: display_name
return: the display name for the material

Sketchup::Material#materialType.description:
The materialType method retrieves the type of the material. Types include:

  - 0 = solid (Sketchup::Material::MATERIAL_SOLID),
  - 1 = textured (Sketchup::Material::MATERIAL_TEXTURED),
  - 2 = colorized textured (Sketchup::Material::MATERIAL_COLORIZED_TEXTURED).

The constants where added in SketchUp 2015.
Sketchup::Material#materialType.name: materialType
return:
the material type for the Material object. See
summary for details.

Sketchup::Material#name.description:
The name method retrieves the name of the material. This is the
internal name of the object which should be used for retrieving
the material from the model's material list.

Use .display_name to display the name in the UI.
Sketchup::Material#name.name: name
return: the name of the Material object

Sketchup::Material#name=.description: The {#name=} method sets the name of the material.
Sketchup::Material#name=.name: name=

Sketchup::Material#owner_type.description:
The {#owner_type} method is used to determine if the material is owned
by a {Sketchup::Materials}.

Returned value is one of:
* +Sketchup::Material::OWNER_MANAGER+
* +Sketchup::Material::OWNER_IMAGE+
* +Sketchup::Material::OWNER_LAYER+
Sketchup::Material#owner_type.name: owner_type

Sketchup::Material#save_as.description:
The {#save_as} method is used to write a material to a SKM file.

You must remember to append ".skm" to the filename as this will not be done
automatically.
Sketchup::Material#save_as.name: save_as
parameters: the path to the SKM file to load.

Sketchup::Material#texture.description: The texture method retrieves the texture of the material.
Sketchup::Material#texture.name: texture
return:
the Texture object within the Material.
Returns nil if the Material does not have a texture.

Sketchup::Material#texture=.description:
The texture= method sets the texture for the material.

Setting the texture to +nil+ will turn it into a solid color
Sketchup::Material#texture=.name: texture=

Sketchup::Material#use_alpha?.description:
The use_alpha? method tells if the material uses transparency.

Note that this is not affected by the alpha value of the color object. Only
the .alpha value and transparent texture will make this method return true.
Sketchup::Material#use_alpha?.name: use_alpha?

Sketchup::Material#write_thumbnail.description: The write_thumbnail method writes a bitmap thumbnail to the given file name.
Sketchup::Material#write_thumbnail.name: write_thumbnail
parameters: The file path for the thumbnail.
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Materials.description:
A collection of Materials objects. Each model contains a Materials collection
that can be accessed via Model.materials.
Sketchup::Materials.name: Materials

Sketchup::Materials#[].description:
The {#[]} method is used to retrieve a material by index or name.

The {#at} method is an alias of {#[]}

Sketchup::Materials#add.description:
Add a new Material.  When called with no arguments, this will generate a
new unique name for the new Material.  If a name is given, it will check
to see if there is already a material with that name.  If there is already
a material with the given name, then a new unique name is generated using
the given name as a base.
Sketchup::Materials#add.name: add
parameters: The name of the new material.

Sketchup::Materials#add_observer.description:
The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the materials
collection.
Sketchup::Materials#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Materials#at.description:
The {#[]} method is used to retrieve a material by index or name.

The {#at} method is an alias of {#[]}
Sketchup::Materials#at.name: at

Sketchup::Materials#current.description:
The current method is used to get the current material, i.e. the material
that the user has selected in the Materials dialog.
Sketchup::Materials#current.name: current

Sketchup::Materials#current=.description: The current= method is used to set the current material.
Sketchup::Materials#current=.name: current=

Sketchup::Materials#each.description: The {#each} method is used to iterate through all of the materials.
Sketchup::Materials#each.name: each

Sketchup::Materials#length.description: The number of materials in the collection.
Sketchup::Materials#length.name: length

Sketchup::Materials#load.description:
The {#load} method is used to load a material from file into the model.

If a matching material exist in the model that will be returned instead.
Sketchup::Materials#load.name: load
parameters: the path to the SKM file to load.
return: the new loaded material, or existing material.

Sketchup::Materials#purge_unused.description: The purge_unused method is used to remove unused materials.
Sketchup::Materials#purge_unused.name: purge_unused

Sketchup::Materials#remove.description:
Remove a given material.

NOTE: On SketchUp versions prior to 2014 there is a bug in this method that
could potentially lead to file corruption. If you call Materials.remove on a
material that is painted onto any entity in the active model (e.g. faces,
edges, groups, ...), then calling this method will not successfully unpaint
the entity and remove the material from the model.
You must first unpaint all of the entities that respond to .material
and .back_material before calling Materials.remove.
Sketchup::Materials#remove.name: remove
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Materials#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove an observer from the materials
collection.
Sketchup::Materials#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Materials#size.description:
The number of materials in the collection.

The {#size} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::Materials#size.name: size

Sketchup::Materials#unique_name.description:
The {#unique_name} method is used to retrieve a unique name from the
materials collection that is based on the provided one. If provided name is
unique it will be returned, otherwise any trailing indices will be replaced
by a new index.
Sketchup::Materials#unique_name.name: unique_name

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver.description: This observer interface is implemented to react to materials events.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver.name: MaterialsObserver

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialAd.description: The {#onMaterialAdd} method is invoked whenever a new material is added.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialAd.name: onMaterialAdd

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialCh.description:
The {#onMaterialChange} method is invoked whenever a material's texture image
is altered.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialCh.name: onMaterialChange

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialRe.description:
The {#onMaterialRefChange} method is invoked whenever the number of entities
that a material is painted on changes. This could be due to the user
manually painting something, but it could also be when faces are split,
pasted, push-pulled, deleted, etc.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialRe.name: onMaterialRefChange

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialRe.description: The {#onMaterialRemove} method is invoked whenever a material is deleted.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialRe.name: onMaterialRemove

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialSe.description:
The {#onMaterialSetCurrent} method is invoked whenever a different material
is selected in the Materials dialog.

The materials parameter might be Nil when the material is picked from the
materials libraries and not yet added to the model.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialSe.name: onMaterialSetCurrent

Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialUn.description:
The {#onMaterialUndoRedo} method is invoked whenever a material is altered
and then those changes are undone or redone.
Sketchup::MaterialsObserver#onMaterialUn.name: onMaterialUndoRedo

Sketchup::Menu#add_item.description:
The {#add_item} method is used to add a menu item to the specified menu.

This method takes a block that defines the action to perform when the menu
item is selected.

The item id that is returned can be used when adding an optional
validation procedure for the menu item.
Sketchup::Menu#add_item.name: add_item

Sketchup::Menu#add_separator.description: The {#add_separator} method is used to add a menu separator to a menu.
Sketchup::Menu#add_separator.name: add_separator

Sketchup::Menu#add_submenu.description: The {#add_submenu} method is used to add a sub-menu to a menu.
Sketchup::Menu#add_submenu.name: add_submenu
parameters: The title of the sub menu.

Sketchup::Menu#set_validation_proc.description:
The {#set_validation_proc} method is used to specify the menu validation
procedure. Your procedure should return either MF_ENABLED, MF_DISABLED,
MF_CHECKED, MF_UNCHECKED, or MF_GRAYED.
Sketchup::Menu#set_validation_proc.name: set_validation_proc
parameters: The numerical identifier for the menu item.

Sketchup::Model.description:
This is the interface to a SketchUp model. The model is the 3D drawing that
the user is working with, and it serves as the "entry point" for most Ruby
API interactions. The Sketchup.active_model method gives you a handle to the
current model, and from there you can use the model-level methods to start
getting information and making changes.

Constants:
Product Family
- Model::ProTrial
- Model::ProLicensed
- Model::MakeTrial
- Model::MakeTrialExpired
Sketchup::Model.name: Model

Sketchup::Model#abort_operation.description:
The {#abort_operation} method aborts the current operation started with the
start_operation method.

The {#abort_operation} method is normally called from inside of a rescue
clause to cancel an operation if something goes wrong.
Sketchup::Model#abort_operation.name: abort_operation
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful

Sketchup::Model#active_entities.description:
Returns an {Sketchup::Entities} object which contains
the entities in the open group or component instance. If no group or
component is open for editing then this will be the same as {#entities}.

To perform actions upon the current set of entities the user is working with
then this is the method to use. Entities selected by the user will be a
subset of the active entities.
Sketchup::Model#active_entities.name: active_entities

Sketchup::Model#active_layer.description:
The {#active_layer} method retrieves the active Layer.

The default layer in SketchUp is layer 0.
Sketchup::Model#active_layer.name: active_layer

Sketchup::Model#active_layer=.description: The {#active_layer=} method sets the active {Sketchup::Layer} object.
Sketchup::Model#active_layer=.name: active_layer=
parameters: The layer to be set as the active layer.

Sketchup::Model#active_path.description: Returns an array containing the sequence of entities the user has double-clicked on for editing. This allows one to determine whether they are in component edit mode and where in the model they are. For example, if a user has double-clicked into a component to edit its geometry, and then double clicked into a sub-group to edit that, the active_path might contain: [, ]
Sketchup::Model#active_path.name: active_path
return:
array of entities showing where the user is
currently editing.

Sketchup::Model#active_path=.description: The {#active_path=} method is used to open a given instance path for editing.
Sketchup::Model#active_path=.name: active_path=
parameters: Passing +nil+ or an empty array will close all open instances.

Sketchup::Model#active_view.description: The {#active_view} method returns the active View object for this model.
Sketchup::Model#active_view.name: active_view

Sketchup::Model#add_note.description:
Add a text note to the Model.  The position of the note is given as relative
window positions between 0 and 1.  For example, the following command
would create a note that start 1/10 of the ways down the screen from the
upper left corner of the window.
Sketchup::Model#add_note.name: add_note
parameters: A distance along the x axis between 0 and 1.
A distance along the y axis between 0 and 1.
return:
a note object or an exception if it is
unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Model#add_observer.description: The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the current object.
Sketchup::Model#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Model#attribute_dictionaries.description:
The {#attribute_dictionaries} method retrieves the AttributeDictionaries
object that is associated with the Model.
Sketchup::Model#attribute_dictionaries.name: attribute_dictionaries
return:
the AttributeDictionaries
object associated with the entity, or nil if there are
no attribute_dictionary objects associated with the
model. Care must be taken if nil is returned, for
example: invoking attribute_dictionaries.length will
throw a NoMethodError exception, not return 0.

Sketchup::Model#attribute_dictionary.description:
Returns the Sketchup::AttributeDictionary object that is specified by
name.  If the model does not have an attribute dictionary that
corresponds to name, returns either nil, or a creates an attribute
dictionary.  If the optional second argument is true, and there is no
attribute dictionary that corresponds to name, a new attribute
dictionary is created.
Sketchup::Model#attribute_dictionary.name: attribute_dictionary
parameters:
The name of the dictionary you are attempting to
retrieve.

if set to true an attribute dictionary of the
given "name" will be created if not found.
return:
an attribute dictionary object if
successful, nil if unsuccessful

Sketchup::Model#axes.description: The {#axes} method returns the drawing axes for the model.
Sketchup::Model#axes.name: axes

Sketchup::Model#behavior.description: The behavior method retrieves the behavior of the model.
Sketchup::Model#behavior.name: behavior
return: behavior object for the model if successful

Sketchup::Model#bounds.description:
The {#bounds} method is used to retrieve the {Geom::BoundingBox} bounding the
contents of a {Sketchup::Model}.
Sketchup::Model#bounds.name: bounds

Sketchup::Model#classifications.description:
The {#classifications} method is used to retrieve the Classifications object
for this model.
Sketchup::Model#classifications.name: classifications

Sketchup::Model#close.description:
The close method is used to close this model. On Mac OS, only the active
model can be closed. On Windows, since there can be only one document open,
this method will perform a File/New operation.
Sketchup::Model#close.name: close
parameters:
If true, model changes will be
ignored and save prompts will be suppressed.
If false, changes will not be ignored and save
prompts will be displayed normally.

Sketchup::Model#close_active.description:
The {#close_active} method is used to close the currently active (open) group
or component.
Sketchup::Model#close_active.name: close_active
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Model#commit_operation.description:
The commit_operation method commits an operation for undo.

The commit_operation method is normally called at the end of a method to
commit the operation that the method performs.
Sketchup::Model#commit_operation.name: commit_operation
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful

Sketchup::Model#definitions.description:
The {#definitions} method retrieves a definition list containing all of the
component definitions in the model.
Sketchup::Model#definitions.name: definitions

Sketchup::Model#description.description:
The description method retrieves a description of the model as found in the
Model Info > Files panel.

The returned description can be empty. The default description for all models
is empty.
Sketchup::Model#description.name: description

Sketchup::Model#description=.description: The {#description=} method sets the description of the model.
Sketchup::Model#description=.name: description=
parameters: the description string to be set.

Sketchup::Model#drawing_element_visible?.description:
The {#drawing_element_visible?} method reports whether the given drawing
element in an instance path is visible given the current model options.
Sketchup::Model#drawing_element_visible?.name: drawing_element_visible?

Sketchup::Model#edit_transform.description:
Returns the transformation of the current component edit session. If a user
has double-clicked to edit a component's geometry, this will
return the transformation of that component, relative to its parent's
origin. This allows one to correctly calculate "local" transformations of
a given entity regardless of whether the user is in edit mode.
Sketchup::Model#edit_transform.name: edit_transform

Sketchup::Model#entities.description:
The {#entities} method returns an {Sketchup::Entities} object containing the
entities in the root of model.
Sketchup::Model#entities.name: entities

Sketchup::Model#export.description:
The export method is used to export a given file format. It knows which
format to export based on the file extension you place on the file name.
For example, a filename of "thing.obj" will export an OBJ file, whereas
"thing.dae" will export a COLLADA file.

For SketchUp Pro 7.1+, valid extensions include dae, kmz, 3ds, dwg,
dxf, fbx, obj, wrl, and xsi. SketchUp Free only supports dae and kmz.

Format Support Changes:
* SketchUp 7.1 added COLLADA (.dae) export capability.
* SketchUp Pro 2015+ added IFC export capability.
* SketchUp Pro 2016+ added PDF export capability.
* SketchUp Pro 2018+ added options for all 3D exporters.

See the {file:pages/exporter_options.md Exporter Options} file for information
on creating a valid hash for the various exporters.
Sketchup::Model#export.name: export

Sketchup::Model#find_entity_by_id.description:
Finds and returns entities by their entityID or GUID.

GUIDs looked up are only relevant to Group and ComponentInstance as these
GUIDs are persistent. ComponentDefinition and Model GUIDs are not persistent
and are not looked up.

When given an array of IDs, an array is returned with a 1:1 mapping to the
input arguments. This array may contain nil values if some ids were not
found. You cannot look up a mix of entityIDs and GUIDs in the same call.
Sketchup::Model#find_entity_by_id.name: find_entity_by_id
parameters:
Pass either a series of ids or a single array containing
ids. Ids must either be entityID Integers or GUID
Strings.
return:
Returns an array with Entity  objects for each id
found and nil otherwise. Single Entity or nil when
