Sketchup::SectionPlane.description:
The SectionPlane class represents a section plane in a SketchUp model. Note
that prior to SketchUp 2014 there was no way to create a SectionPlane object
using Ruby. For older versions of SketchUp, you must manually create a
section plane with the Section Plane Tool in SketchUp and then query the
entities array to find the SectionPlane object.
Sketchup::SectionPlane.name: SectionPlane

Sketchup::SectionPlane#activate.description:
The activate method is used to make the section plane the active one of its
parent component/group.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#activate.name: activate

Sketchup::SectionPlane#active?.description: The active? method indicates whether the section plane is active or not.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#active?.name: active?

Sketchup::SectionPlane#get_plane.description:
The get_plane method is used to retrieve the plane that the section plane is
on.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#get_plane.name: get_plane
return:
plane - a plane. See the Geom module and Array class
for further information on planes.

Sketchup::SectionPlane#name.description: The {#name} method is used to retrieve the name of the section plane.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#name.name: name

Sketchup::SectionPlane#name=.description: The {#name=} method is used to set the name of a section plane.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#name=.name: name=
parameters: The new name for the section plane object.

Sketchup::SectionPlane#set_plane.description:
The set_plane method is used to set the plane that the section plane is
on.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#set_plane.name: set_plane
parameters: An array representing the new plane,

Sketchup::SectionPlane#symbol.description: The {#symbol} method is used to retrieve the symbol of the section plane.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#symbol.name: symbol

Sketchup::SectionPlane#symbol=.description: The {#symbol=} method is used to set the symbol of a section plane.
Sketchup::SectionPlane#symbol=.name: symbol=
parameters: The new symbol for the section plane object.

Sketchup::Selection.description: A set of the currently selected entities. Use the Model.selection method to get a Selection object. Note that the order of entities (selection[0], selection[1] and so on) in the set is in no particular order and should not be assumed to be in the same order as the user selected the entities.
Sketchup::Selection.name: Selection

Sketchup::Selection#[].description:
The {#[]} method is used to retrieve an {Sketchup::Entity} from the selection
by index. Index 0 is the first entity in the selection.

This method is not very efficient. If you need to look at every entity in
the selection, consider using {#each} instead of using this method
to manually grab each one.
parameters: The index of the Entity object to retrieve.

Sketchup::Selection#add.description:
The add method is used to add entities to the selection.  Entities that are
added to the Selection are visually indicated by the selection bounding box.

You can pass it individual Entities or an Array of Entities:
Note that the add, remove, and toggle methods are all aliases for one
another. So if you call remove on an entity that is not selected, it will
be toggled to be selected, not removed! Be cautious when writing your code to
not make the assumption about the currently selected state of a given entity.
Sketchup::Selection#add.name: add
return: the number of Entity objects added

Sketchup::Selection#add_observer.description: The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the selection object.
Sketchup::Selection#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Selection#at.description: The {#at} method is an alias for {#[]}.
Sketchup::Selection#at.name: at
parameters: The index of the Entity object to retrieve.

Sketchup::Selection#clear.description: The clear method is used to clear the selection.
Sketchup::Selection#clear.name: clear

Sketchup::Selection#contains?.description: The {contains?} method is and alias of {#include?}.
Sketchup::Selection#contains?.name: contains?

Sketchup::Selection#each.description:
The each method is used to iterate through all of the selected entities.

If you want to do something with all of the selected Entities, this is more
efficient than using [].
Sketchup::Selection#each.name: each

Sketchup::Selection#empty?.description:
The empty? method is used to determine if there are entities in the
selection.
Sketchup::Selection#empty?.name: empty?

Sketchup::Selection#first.description:
The first method is used to retrieve the first selected entity

Returns nil if nothing is selected. This method is useful when you know that
only a single entity is selected, or you are only interested in the first
selected entity.
Sketchup::Selection#first.name: first
return: the first selected Entity object if successful

Sketchup::Selection#include?.description:
The {include?} method is used to determine if a given {Sketchup::Entity} is
in the selection.
Sketchup::Selection#include?.name: include?

Sketchup::Selection#invert.description: The {#invert} method is used to invert the selection.
Sketchup::Selection#invert.name: invert

Sketchup::Selection#is_curve?.description:
The is_curve? method is used to determine if the selection contains all
edges that belong to a single curve.
Sketchup::Selection#is_curve?.name: is_curve?

Sketchup::Selection#is_surface?.description:
The is_surface? method is used to determine if the selection contains only
all of the faces that are part of a single curved surface.
Sketchup::Selection#is_surface?.name: is_surface?

Sketchup::Selection#length.description: The {#length} method is used to retrieve the number of selected entities.
Sketchup::Selection#length.name: length

Sketchup::Selection#model.description: The model method retrieves the model for the selection.
Sketchup::Selection#model.name: model
return:
the model that includes the selection if
successful

Sketchup::Selection#nitems.description: The {#nitems} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::Selection#nitems.name: nitems

Sketchup::Selection#remove.description:
The remove method is used to remove entities from the selection.

You can pass it individual Entities or an Array of Entities:
Note that the add, remove, and toggle methods are all aliases for one
another. So if you call remove on an entity that is not selected, it will
be toggled to be selected, not removed! Be cautious when writing your code to
not make the assumption about the currently selected state of a given entity.
Sketchup::Selection#remove.name: remove
return: the number of Entity objects removed

Sketchup::Selection#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove an observer from the selection
object.
Sketchup::Selection#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Selection#shift.description:
The shift method is used to remove the first entity from the selection and
returns it.
Sketchup::Selection#shift.name: shift
return:
the first Entity object in the selection set
if successful

Sketchup::Selection#single_object?.description:
The single_object? method is used to determine if the selection contains a
single object.

It can either be a single Entity or a group of Entities for which is_curve?
or is_surface? will return true.
Sketchup::Selection#single_object?.name: single_object?

Sketchup::Selection#size.description: The {#size} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::Selection#size.name: size

Sketchup::Selection#toggle.description:
The toggle method is used to change whether an entity is part of the
selection. Entities that are not already selected
are added. Entities that are already selected are removed.

You can pass it individual Entities or an Array of Entities:
Note that the add, remove, and toggle methods are all aliases for one
another. So if you call remove on an entity that is not selected, it will
be toggled to be selected, not removed! Be cautious when writing your code to
not make the assumption about the currently selected state of a given entity.
Sketchup::Selection#toggle.name: toggle
return: the number of Entity objects changed

Sketchup::SelectionObserver.description: This observer interface is implemented to react to selection events.
Sketchup::SelectionObserver.name: SelectionObserver

Sketchup::SelectionObserver#onSelectionB.description:
The {#onSelectionBulkChange} method is called whenever items are added or
removed from the selection set.

The {#onSelectionBulkChange} callback will not trigger if the selection
is cleared by clicking on empty model space. Use the {#onSelectionCleared}
method to catch this case.
Sketchup::SelectionObserver#onSelectionB.name: onSelectionBulkChange

Sketchup::SelectionObserver#onSelectionC.description:
The {#onSelectionCleared} method is called when the selection is completely
emptied.
Sketchup::SelectionObserver#onSelectionC.name: onSelectionCleared

Sketchup::Set.description:
The set class represents a collection of unique objects. This class is useful
for keeping track of a group of related entities, kind of like a selection
set that stays around for as long as you need it to.

To make a set of your own, create an empty one using Sketchup::Set.new, and
then add items to it.
Sketchup::Set.name: Set

Sketchup::Set#clear.description: The clear method is used to clear all objects out of the set.
Sketchup::Set#clear.name: clear

Sketchup::Set#contains?.description: The {#contains?} method is an alias for {#include?}.
Sketchup::Set#contains?.name: contains?

Sketchup::Set#delete.description: The delete object is used to delete or remove an object from the set.
Sketchup::Set#delete.name: delete
return: object - the object that was deleted.

Sketchup::Set#each.description: The each method is used to iterate through all of the objects in the set.
Sketchup::Set#each.name: each

Sketchup::Set#empty?.description: The empty? method is used to determine whether the set is empty.
Sketchup::Set#empty?.name: empty?
return:
status - true if the set is empty, false if it is not
empty.

Sketchup::Set#include?.description:
The {#include?} method is used to determine if the set includes a particular
object.
Sketchup::Set#include?.name: include?

Sketchup::Set#insert.description: The insert method is used to insert an object into the set.
Sketchup::Set#insert.name: insert
parameters: The object to be inserted into the set.
return: size - the number of objects in the set

Sketchup::Set#length.description: The {#length} method is an alias for {#size}.
Sketchup::Set#length.name: length

Sketchup::Set#size.description: The {#size} method is used to determine the number of objects in the set.
Sketchup::Set#size.name: size

Sketchup::Set#to_a.description: The to_a method is used to get an Array of the entities in your Set.
Sketchup::Set#to_a.name: to_a
return: array - The Array of the entities in the Set.

Sketchup::ShadowInfo.description:
The ShadowInfo class contains method to extract the shadow information for a
model. The majority of the shadow information returned exists in the Model
Info > Location and Model Info > Shadows dialogs inside SketchUp.

The following shadow information keys are maintained in SketchUp:

- +City+ (in Model Info > Geo-location > Set Manual Location...) Note that 'City' is called 'Location' in the UI
- +Country+ (in Model Info > Geo-location > Set Manual Location...)
- +Dark+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +DayOfYear+
- +DaylightSavings+
- +DisplayNorth+ (in View > Toolbars > Solar North) Note that 'Toolbar' is called 'Tool Palettes' on Mac
- +DisplayOnAllFaces+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +DisplayOnGroundPlane+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +DisplayShadows+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +EdgesCastShadows+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +Latitude+ (in Model Info > Geo-location > Set Manual Location...)
- +Light+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +Longitude+ (in Model Info > Geo-location > Set Manual Location...)
- +NorthAngle+ (in View > Toolbars > Solar North) Note that 'Toolbar' is called 'Tool Palettes' on Mac
- +ShadowTime+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +ShadowTime_time_t+ (ShadowTime in Epoch time)
- +SunDirection+ (Generated based on ShadowTime)
- +SunRise+ (Generated based on ShadowTime)
- +SunRise_time_t+ (SunRise in Epoch time)
- +SunSet+ (Generated based on ShadowTime)
- +SunSet_time_t+ (SunSet in Epoch time)
- +TZOffset+ (in Window > Shadows)
- +UseSunForAllShading+ (in Window > Shadows)

You access the ShadowInfo object by calling Model.shadow_info:
Sketchup::ShadowInfo.name: ShadowInfo

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#[].description: The [] method retrieves a value from the array of keys
parameters: The key of the shadowinfo value to retrieve.

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#[]=.description:
The set value []= method is used to set the value in the array of shadow
info options.
parameters: The key of the shadowinfo value to set.
return:
the value that was set if successful, or false
if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#add_observer.description: The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the current object.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#count.description: The count method is inherited from the Enumerable mix-in module.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#count.name: count

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each.description:
The {#each} method iterates through all of the shadow information key/value
pairs.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each.name: each

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each_key.description: The each_key method iterates through all of the shadow information keys.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each_key.name: each_key

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each_pair.description: The {#each_pair} method is an alias for {#each}.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#each_pair.name: each_pair

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#keys.description:
The keys method is a class method that returns an array with all of the
attribute keys
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#keys.name: keys

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#length.description:
The {#length} method returns the number of options in the shadow options
collection
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#length.name: length

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove an observer from the current
object.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::ShadowInfo#size.description: The {#size} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo#size.name: size

Sketchup::ShadowInfo.each_key.description: The each_key method iterates through all of the shadow information keys.
Sketchup::ShadowInfo.each_key.name: each_key

Sketchup::ShadowInfo.keys.description:
The keys method is a class method that returns an array with all of the
attribute keys
Sketchup::ShadowInfo.keys.name: keys

Sketchup::ShadowInfoObserver.description:
This observer interface is implemented to react to changes to the shadow
settings.
Sketchup::ShadowInfoObserver.name: ShadowInfoObserver

Sketchup::ShadowInfoObserver#onShadowInf.description:
The {#onShadowInfoChanged} method is invoked whenever the user alters a
setting inside the Shadows and Model Info dialogs. The type parameter
contains a number identifying which option was altered. Here are the types to
expect:

- 0 = Time/Date sliders
- 1 = Display Shadows checkbox
- 2 = Light/Dark sliders
- 3 = Geographic Location (in Model Info > Location)
- 4 = Solar Orientation (in Model Info > Location)
- 7 = Use Sun for Shading checkbox
- 8 = Display from Edges checkbox
- 9 = Display on Ground checkbox
- 10 = Display on Faces checkbox
Sketchup::ShadowInfoObserver#onShadowInf.name: onShadowInfoChanged
parameters: A number identifying which setting was changed.

Sketchup::Skp.description:
The {Sketchup::Skp} module is used to read metadata from external SketchUp
files without loading the whole file.
Sketchup::Skp.name: Skp

Sketchup::Skp.read_guid.description:
The {.read_guid} method is used to read the GUID, globally unique identifier,
for an external model.

In SketchUp, GUIDs are used to test if {Sketchup::ComponentDefinition}s and
{Sketchup::Model}s match (a component being an embedded model).
When you insert a component to a model, its GUID is compared to existing
component definitions in that model, and if there is a match the existing
component definition is re-used rather than a duplicate being added.
When a component definition is modified or a model is saved, their GUIDs are
renewed.
Sketchup::Skp.read_guid.name: read_guid

Sketchup::Style.description:
The Style class contains methods for modifying information about a specific
style. Styles are a collection of display settings that tell SketchUp how to
draw the model.
Sketchup::Style.name: Style

Sketchup::Style#description.description: The {#description} method gets the description for a {Sketchup::Style}.
Sketchup::Style#description.name: description

Sketchup::Style#description=.description: The {#description=} method sets the description for a {Sketchup::Style}.
Sketchup::Style#description=.name: description=

Sketchup::Style#name.description: The {#name} method gets the name for a {Sketchup::Style}.
Sketchup::Style#name.name: name

Sketchup::Style#name=.description: The {#name=} method sets the name for a {Sketchup::Style}.
Sketchup::Style#name=.name: name=

Sketchup::Styles.description:
The Styles class contains methods for manipulating a collection of styles in
a model. Typically, you will access this via the active_model:
Sketchup::Styles.name: Styles

Sketchup::Styles#[].description: The {#[]} method is used to retrieves a style by either name or index.

Sketchup::Styles#active_style.description:
The {#active_style} method is used to retrieve the active style.

While {#selected_style} is the style being selected in the Style Browser,
the #{active_style} is a different object also including any unsaved style
changes. These changes are silently dropped once a new style is selected.
To save these changes to the selected style, call #{update_selected_style}.
Sketchup::Styles#active_style.name: active_style

Sketchup::Styles#active_style_changed.description:
The {#active_style_changed} method tells you if the active style has been
edited by the user since it was last saved.
Sketchup::Styles#active_style_changed.name: active_style_changed

Sketchup::Styles#add_style.description:
The {#add_style} method is used to create and load a style from the given
file.
Sketchup::Styles#add_style.name: add_style
parameters:
+true+ if you want to set the style to be the
active style.

Sketchup::Styles#each.description: The {#each} method is used to iterate through styles.
Sketchup::Styles#each.name: each

Sketchup::Styles#length.description: The {#length} method is an alias of {#size}.
Sketchup::Styles#length.name: length

Sketchup::Styles#parent.description: The {#parent} method is used to return the model for the styles.
Sketchup::Styles#parent.name: parent

Sketchup::Styles#purge_unused.description: The {#purge_unused} method is used to remove unused styles from the model.
Sketchup::Styles#purge_unused.name: purge_unused

Sketchup::Styles#selected_style.description:
The {#selected_style} method is used to retrieve the style currently
selected in the Styles Browser.
Sketchup::Styles#selected_style.name: selected_style

Sketchup::Styles#selected_style=.description: The {#selected_style=} method is used to set the currently selected style.
Sketchup::Styles#selected_style=.name: selected_style=

Sketchup::Styles#size.description:
The {#size} method is used to retrieve the number of styles in the
collection.
Sketchup::Styles#size.name: size

Sketchup::Styles#update_selected_style.description:
The {#update_selected_style} method commits the current style settings to the
style selected in the Style Browser.
Sketchup::Styles#update_selected_style.name: update_selected_style

Sketchup::Text.description: The Text class contains method to manipulate a Text entity object.
Sketchup::Text.name: Text

Sketchup::Text#arrow_type.description:
The arrow_type method retrieves the current arrow type used for the leader
text.

Valid arrow types are 0 for none, 2 for dot, 3 for closed arrow, 4 for open
arrow.
Sketchup::Text#arrow_type.name: arrow_type
return:
a numerical representation for the type of
arrow.

Sketchup::Text#arrow_type=.description:
The arrow_type= method sets the arrow type used for leader text.

Valid arrow types are 0 for none, 2 for dot, 3 for closed arrow, 4 for open
arrow.
Sketchup::Text#arrow_type=.name: arrow_type=
parameters:
A numerical representation of the type of arrow to be
set.
return:
a numerical representation for the type of
arrow.

Sketchup::Text#attached_to.description:
The {#attached_to} method returns an array of the attached
{Sketchup::InstancePath} object and the {Geom::Point3d}.
Sketchup::Text#attached_to.name: attached_to

Sketchup::Text#attached_to=.description:
The {#attached_to=} method will attach the {Sketchup::Text} to another
{Sketchup::DrawingElement}.
Sketchup::Text#attached_to=.name: attached_to=

Sketchup::Text#display_leader=.description:
The display_leader= method accepts true or false for whether to display the
leader.

Leader text that is not displayed is set to Hidden type.
Sketchup::Text#display_leader=.name: display_leader=
parameters:
true if you want to display the leader text, false if
you do not want to display the leader text.

Sketchup::Text#display_leader?.description: The display_leader? method returns the status of the leader.
Sketchup::Text#display_leader?.name: display_leader?

Sketchup::Text#has_leader?.description: The has_leader method is used to determine if the Text object has a leader.
Sketchup::Text#has_leader?.name: has_leader?

Sketchup::Text#leader_type.description: The leader_type method retrieves the currently set leader type.
Sketchup::Text#leader_type.name: leader_type
return:
a numerical value representing the currently
set leader type.

Sketchup::Text#leader_type=.description:
The leader_type = method sets the leader type.

Valid leader types are 0 for none, 1 for View-based, and 2 for Pushpin
Sketchup::Text#leader_type=.name: leader_type=
parameters:
A numerical value representing the leader type to be
set.
return:
a numerical value representing the leader type
you just set.

Sketchup::Text#line_weight.description:
The line_weight method returns a line weight in number of pixels.

Defalt line weight is 1.
Sketchup::Text#line_weight.name: line_weight

Sketchup::Text#line_weight=.description:
The line_weight= method sets the line weight in pixels.

Default line weight is 1.
Sketchup::Text#line_weight=.name: line_weight=
parameters: The line weight to be set (in pixels).
return: The line weight that has been set.

Sketchup::Text#point.description: The point method is used to get the point associated with the text.
Sketchup::Text#point.name: point

Sketchup::Text#point=.description: The point= method is used to set the point associated with the text.
Sketchup::Text#point=.name: point=
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Text#set_text.description:
The set_text method is used to set the text within a Text object without
recording an Undo operation.
Sketchup::Text#set_text.name: set_text
parameters: The string to be set within the Text object.

Sketchup::Text#text.description: The text method is used to retrieve the string version of a Text object.
Sketchup::Text#text.name: text
return:
the string representation of the Text
object

Sketchup::Text#text=.description: The text= method is used to set the string version of a Text object.
Sketchup::Text#text=.name: text=

Sketchup::Text#vector.description: The vector method is used to get the vector associated with the text.
Sketchup::Text#vector.name: vector

Sketchup::Text#vector=.description: The vector= method is used to set the vector associated with the text.
Sketchup::Text#vector=.name: vector=

Sketchup::Texture.description:
The Texture class contains methods for obtaining information about textures
that are part of your materials in your model (within the In-Model section
of the Materials Browser). Remember, textures are repeatable images that
"tile" when painted on a surface.
Sketchup::Texture.name: Texture

Sketchup::Texture#average_color.description:
The average_color method retrieves a color object with the average color
found in the texture.
Sketchup::Texture#average_color.name: average_color
return:
a color object (if successful), nil if
unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Texture#filename.description:
The {#filename} method retrieves the entire path, including the file, for a
texture object.
Sketchup::Texture#filename.name: filename
return:
a string representation of the path and
filename used for the texture.

Sketchup::Texture#height.description:
The height method is used to get the height of a repeatable texture image,
in inches.
Sketchup::Texture#height.name: height
return: the height, in inches, of the texture pattern

Sketchup::Texture#image_height.description:
The image_height method retrieves the height of the repeatable texture
image, in pixels.
Sketchup::Texture#image_height.name: image_height
return:
the height, in pixels, of the texture
pattern

Sketchup::Texture#image_rep.description:
The {#image_rep} method returns a copy of a {Sketchup::ImageRep} object
representing the texture pixel data.
Sketchup::Texture#image_rep.name: image_rep
parameters: Set to +true+ to obtain the colorized version.

Sketchup::Texture#image_width.description:
The image_width method retrieves the width of the repeatable texture image,
in pixels.
Sketchup::Texture#image_width.name: image_width
return:
the width, in pixels, of the texture
pattern

Sketchup::Texture#size=.description:
The size= method allows you to set the size of the repeatable texture image,
in inches,
Sketchup::Texture#size=.name: size=
parameters:
The size, in inches, of the texture. This number will
apply to height and width to keep aspect ratio.
You can also pass as a parameter an array of two
numeric values which will set width and height
regardless of maintaining the height/width ratio.
return:
the size, in inches, of the texture. This number
will apply to height and width to keep aspect ratio.
If you have passed in an array of two numbers for width
and height, the same array will be returned if
successful.

Sketchup::Texture#valid?.description: The valid? method ensures that a texture is valid.
Sketchup::Texture#valid?.name: valid?

Sketchup::Texture#width.description:
The width method is used to get the width of a repeatable texture image,
in inches.
Sketchup::Texture#width.name: width
return: the width, in inches, of the texture pattern

Sketchup::Texture#write.description:
Writes the texture to file with option to preserve the color adjustments made
by the material.
Sketchup::Texture#write.name: write
parameters: The file path to write the texture to.

Boolean - Allows for the texture to
be exported with the color adjustments.

Sketchup::TextureWriter.description:
The TextureWriter class is used primarily for writing the textures used in a
SketchUp model out to files as part of an export for use in another
application. These methods are usually invoked in this order:

  - 1. load - load one or more textures from a model into the TextureWriter.
  - 2. write_all or write - write the texture(s) to file.
Sketchup::TextureWriter.name: TextureWriter

Sketchup::TextureWriter#count.description:
The {#length} method is used to determine the number of textures loaded into
the texture writer.

The {#count} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::TextureWriter#count.name: count
return:
length - the number of textures loaded in the texture
writer

Sketchup::TextureWriter#filename.description:
The filename method is used to retrieve the original filename for a
particular texture.
Sketchup::TextureWriter#filename.name: filename
parameters:
The index or handle of the texture in the texture
writer.
return:
filename - the filename of the texture on the file system.
Textures can be generated without filenames, so if the
texture doesn't have a name write_all will save the
texture to an image file named "i.png". Where i is the
first integer greater than zero which was not already used
for a png file name.

Sketchup::TextureWriter#handle.description:
The handle method is used to retrieve a handle or index for a specific
texture in the texture writer.
Sketchup::TextureWriter#handle.name: handle

Sketchup::TextureWriter#length.description:
The {#length} method is used to determine the number of textures loaded into
the texture writer.

The {#count} method is an alias for {#length}.
Sketchup::TextureWriter#length.name: length
return:
length - the number of textures loaded in the texture
writer

Sketchup::TextureWriter#load.description:
The load method is used to load one or more textures into the texture writer
for writing out to a file.
Sketchup::TextureWriter#load.name: load

Sketchup::TextureWriter#write.description:
The write method is used to write an individual textures, within the texture
writer, to a file. An entity's texture must have been loaded into the texture
writer before this method can be used to write it's texture.

This method will return one of the following status messages. (These are
constants that are defined by the API.)

  - 0 = FILE_WRITE_OK
  - 1 = FILE_WRITE_FAILED_INVALID_TIFF
  - 2 = FILE_WRITE_FAILED_UNKNOWN
Sketchup::TextureWriter#write.name: write

Sketchup::TextureWriter#write_all.description:
The write_all method is used to write all of the textures within the texture
writer to files. It will return one of three status numbers:

  - 0 = FILE_WRITE_OK
  - 1 = FILE_WRITE_FAILED_INVALID_TIFF
  - 2 = FILE_WRITE_FAILED_UNKNOWN
Sketchup::TextureWriter#write_all.name: write_all
parameters: true to use 8.3 DOS name format.
return: status - one of three status messages (see comments.)

Sketchup::Tool.description:
Tool is the interface that you implement to create a SketchUp tool.
See https://github.com/SketchUp/sketchup-ruby-api-tutorials/tree/master/examples/02_custom_tool
for an example of how to create a custom tool in Ruby.

To create a new tool in Ruby, you must define a new class that implements
the methods for the events that you want to respond to. You do not have
to implement methods for every possible event that a Tool can respond to.

Once you have defined a tool class, you select that tool by creating an
instance of it and passing it to {Sketchup::Model#select_tool}. For
example:

  class MyTool
    def activate
      puts 'Your tool has been activated.'
    end
  end

  my_tool = MyTool.new
  Sketchup.active_model.select_tool(my_tool)

The following table contains several constants you can use when check for
certain key presses inside the keyboard handling callbacks:

- +CONSTRAIN_MODIFIER_KEY+ = Shift Key
- +CONSTRAIN_MODIFIER_MASK+ = Shift Key
- +COPY_MODIFIER_KEY+ = Alt/Option on Mac, Ctrl on PC
- +COPY_MODIFIER_MASK+ = Alt/Option on Mac, Ctrl on PC
- +ALT_MODIFIER_KEY+ = Command on Mac, Alt on PC
- +ALT_MODIFIER_MASK+ = Command on Mac, Alt on PC
Sketchup::Tool.name: Tool

Sketchup::Tool#activate.description:
The {#activate} method is called by SketchUp when the tool is selected.
It is a good place to put most of your initialization, such as instance
variables to track the state of the tool.
Sketchup::Tool#activate.name: activate

Sketchup::Tool#deactivate.description:
The {#deactivate} method is called when the tool is deactivated because a
different tool was selected.
Sketchup::Tool#deactivate.name: deactivate

Sketchup::Tool#draw.description:
The {#draw} method is called by SketchUp whenever the view is refreshed to
allow the tool to do its own drawing. If the tool has some temporary graphics
that it wants displayed while it is active, it should implement this method
and draw to the {Sketchup::View}.
Sketchup::Tool#draw.name: draw
parameters: A View object where the method was invoked.

Sketchup::Tool#enableVCB?.description:
The {#enableVCB?} method is used to tell SketchUp whether to allow the user
to enter text into the VCB (value control box, aka the "measurements" panel).
If you do not implement this method, then the vcb is disabled by default.
Sketchup::Tool#enableVCB?.name: enableVCB?
return: Return +true+ if you want the VCB enabled

Sketchup::Tool#getExtents.description:
In order to accurately draw things, SketchUp needs to know the extents of
what it is drawing. If the tool is doing its own drawing, it may need to
implement this method to tell SketchUp the extents of what it will be
drawing. If you don't implement this method, you may find that part of what
the tool is drawing gets clipped to the extents of the rest of the
model.

This must return a {Geom::BoundingBox}. In a typical implementation, you
will create a new {Geom::BoundingBox}, add points to set the extents of the
drawing that the tool will do and then return it.
Sketchup::Tool#getExtents.name: getExtents

Sketchup::Tool#getInstructorContentDirec.description:
The {#getInstructorContentDirectory} method is used to tell SketchUp the
directory containing your Tool's instructor content. To use this, create
a custom instructor directory, put an index.html file inside of it, and then
return that path via this method. If the SketchUp user has the Instructor
window open when they activate your tool, they will see your html file.
Sketchup::Tool#getInstructorContentDirec.name: getInstructorContentDirectory
return: the directory path where the Instructor content exists.

Sketchup::Tool#getMenu.description:
The {#getMenu} method is called by SketchUp to let the tool provide its own
context menu. Most tools will not want to implement this method and,
instead, use the normal context menu found on all entities.

If you do implement this method, the argument is a Menu. You should use the
add_item method to build the context menu.

Your tool will use a standard context menu by default if you do not
implement this method. Implement this method if you want a context-click to
display something other than this default context menu.

In SketchUp 2015 the flags, x, y and view parameters were added. They are
needed if you need to pick the entities under the mouse position. The new
parameters are optional, but if you need to use one you must include them
all.
Sketchup::Tool#getMenu.name: getMenu
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the
modifier keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
Added in SU2015.

The X coordinate on the screen where the
event occurred. Added in SU2015.

The Y coordinate on the screen where the
event occurred. Added in SU2015.

A View object where the method was invoked.
Added in SU2015.

Sketchup::Tool#onCancel.description:
The {#onCancel} method is called by SketchUp to cancel the current operation
of the tool. The typical response will be to reset the tool to its initial
state.

The reason identifies the action that triggered the call. The reason can be
one of the following values:

- +0+: the user canceled the current operation by hitting the escape key.
- +1+: the user re-selected the same tool from the toolbar or menu.
- +2+: the user did an undo while the tool was active.
Sketchup::Tool#onCancel.name: onCancel

Sketchup::Tool#onKeyDown.description:
The {#onKeyDown} method is called by SketchUp when the user presses a key on
the keyboard. If you want to get input from the VCB, you should implement
onUserText rather than this method.

This method is can be used for special keys such as the Shift key, Ctrl key,
and so on, or for just determining which key a user pressed. This method is
actually called for all keys that are pressed.

There are several
"virtual keys" defined as constants you can use.  Their use is cross
platform. They are:

- +VK_ALT+
- +VK_COMMAND+
- +VK_CONTROL+
- +VK_DELETE+
- +VK_DOWN+
- +VK_END+
- +VK_HOME+
- +VK_INSERT+
- +VK_LEFT+
- +VK_MENU+
- +VK_NEXT+
- +VK_PRIOR+
- +VK_RIGHT+
- +VK_SHIFT+
- +VK_SPACE+
- +VK_UP+

V6: There is a bug on Windows where the typematic effect does
not work. Typematic effects work fine on a Mac.
Sketchup::Tool#onKeyDown.name: onKeyDown
parameters:
A value of 1 for a single press of a key.  A value
of 2 if the user has pressed a key and is holding
it down.

A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys at the time of the event.
return:
Return +true+ to prevent SketchUp from processing the
event.

Sketchup::Tool#onKeyUp.description:
The {#onKeyUp} method is called by SketchUp when the user releases a key on
the keyboard.
Sketchup::Tool#onKeyUp.name: onKeyUp
parameters:
A value of 1 for a single press of a key.  A value
of 2 if the user has pressed a key and is holding
it down.

A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys at the time of the event.
return:
Return +true+ to prevent SketchUp from processing the
event.

Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonDoubleClick.description:
The {#onLButtonDoubleClick} is called by SketchUp when the user double clicks
with the left mouse button.
Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonDoubleClick.name: onLButtonDoubleClick
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonDown.description:
The {#onLButtonDown} method is called by SketchUp when the left mouse button
is pressed. Most tools will implement this method.
Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonDown.name: onLButtonDown
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonUp.description:
The {#onLButtonUp} method is called by SketchUp when the left mouse button is
released.
Sketchup::Tool#onLButtonUp.name: onLButtonUp
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonDoubleClick.description:
The {#onMButtonDoubleClick} method is called by SketchUp when the middle
mouse button (on a three button mouse) is double-clicked.

Only implement this method if you want SketchUp to react to a middle mouse
button being double-clicked.
Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonDoubleClick.name: onMButtonDoubleClick
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonDown.description:
The {#onMButtonDown} method is called by SketchUp when the middle mouse
button (on a three button mouse) is down.

The Orbit tool is activated by default when the middle mouse button is down.
Implement this method if you want a middle mouse button to do something
other than invoke the Orbit tool.
Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonDown.name: onMButtonDown
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonUp.description:
The {#onMButtonUp} method is called by SketchUp when the middle mouse button
(on a three button mouse) is released.

SketchUp returns to the previous tool from the Orbit tool when the middle
mouse button is released. Implement this method if you want a middle mouse
button to do something other than return to the previous tool when in the
Orbit tool.
Sketchup::Tool#onMButtonUp.name: onMButtonUp
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onMouseEnter.description:
The {#onMouseEnter} method is called by SketchUp when the mouse enters the
viewport.
Sketchup::Tool#onMouseEnter.name: onMouseEnter

Sketchup::Tool#onMouseLeave.description:
The {#onMouseLeave} method is called by SketchUp when the mouse leaves the
viewport.
Sketchup::Tool#onMouseLeave.name: onMouseLeave

Sketchup::Tool#onMouseMove.description:
The {#onMouseMove} method is called by SketchUp whenever the mouse is moved.
You will often want to implement this method.

Try to make this method as efficient as possible because this method is
called often.
Sketchup::Tool#onMouseMove.name: onMouseMove
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onMouseWheel.description:
The {#onMouseWheel} method is called by SketchUp when the mouse scroll wheel
is used.
Sketchup::Tool#onMouseWheel.name: onMouseWheel
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.

Either +1+ or +-1+ depending on which direction the
mouse wheel scrolled.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
return:
Return +true+ to prevent SketchUp from performing default
zoom action.

Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonDoubleClick.description:
The {#onRButtonDoubleClick} is called by SketchUp when the user double clicks
with the right mouse button.
Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonDoubleClick.name: onRButtonDoubleClick
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonDown.description:
The {#onRButtonDown} method is called by SketchUp when the user presses
the right mouse button. Implement this method, along with the tool.getMenu
method, when you want your tool to do something other than display the
default context menu when the right mouse button is clicked.
Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonDown.name: onRButtonDown
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonUp.description:
The {#onRButtonUp} method is called by SketchUp when the user releases the
right mouse button.
Sketchup::Tool#onRButtonUp.name: onRButtonUp
parameters:
A bit mask that tells the state of the modifier
keys and other mouse buttons at the time.
The X coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.
The Y coordinate on the screen where the event occurred.

Sketchup::Tool#onReturn.description:
The {#onReturn} method is called by SketchUp when the user hit the Return key
to complete an operation in the tool. This method will rarely need to be
implemented.
Sketchup::Tool#onReturn.name: onReturn

Sketchup::Tool#onSetCursor.description:
The {#onSetCursor} method is called by SketchUp when the tool wants to set
the cursor.
Sketchup::Tool#onSetCursor.name: onSetCursor
return: Return +true+ to prevent SketchUp using the default cursor.

Sketchup::Tool#onUserText.description:
The {#onUserText} method is called by SketchUp when the user has typed text
into the VCB and hit return.
Sketchup::Tool#onUserText.name: onUserText
parameters: The text string that was typed into the VCB.
A view object where the method was invoked.

Sketchup::Tool#resume.description:
The {#resume} method is called by SketchUp when the tool becomes active again
after being suspended.
Sketchup::Tool#resume.name: resume

Sketchup::Tool#suspend.description:
The {#suspend} method is called by SketchUp when the tool temporarily becomes
inactive because another tool has been activated. This typically happens
when a viewing tool is activated, such as when orbit is active due to the
middle mouse button.
Sketchup::Tool#suspend.name: suspend

Sketchup::Tools.description:
The Tools class contains methods to manipulate a collection of SketchUp
tools. You access this collection by calling the Model.tools method.
Sketchup::Tools.name: Tools

Sketchup::Tools#active_tool.description: The {#active_tool} method is used to obtain the active Ruby tool.
Sketchup::Tools#active_tool.name: active_tool
return: Returns the active Ruby tool, or `nil` otherwise.

Sketchup::Tools#active_tool_id.description: The active_tool_id method is used to retrieve the active tool's id.
Sketchup::Tools#active_tool_id.name: active_tool_id

Sketchup::Tools#active_tool_name.description: The active_tool_name method is used to retrieve the active tool's name.
Sketchup::Tools#active_tool_name.name: active_tool_name

Sketchup::Tools#add_observer.description: The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the current object.
Sketchup::Tools#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: status - true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Tools#model.description: The model method is used to get the model associated with this tools object.
Sketchup::Tools#model.name: model
return:
model - the Model object associated with this tools
collection.

Sketchup::Tools#pop_tool.description: The pop_tool method is used to pop the last pushed tool on the tool stack.
Sketchup::Tools#pop_tool.name: pop_tool
return:
the last pushed Tool object, if it is a Ruby tool. If a
native tool is active, selects the default native tool
and returns nil.

Sketchup::Tools#push_tool.description:
The push_tool method is used to push (aka activate) a user-defined tool.
See the Tool interface for details on creating your own SketchUp tool.
Sketchup::Tools#push_tool.name: push_tool
return: status - true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::Tools#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove an observer from the current
object.
Sketchup::Tools#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::ToolsObserver.description:
This observer interface is implemented to react to tool events.

Some of the code below mentions +tool_names+ and +tool_ids+. Here is a list
of the common tool IDs and names:

- +21013+ = 3DTextTool
- +21065+ = ArcTool
- +10523+ = CameraDollyTool
- +10508+ = CameraOrbitTool
- +10525+ = CameraPanTool
- +21169+ = PositionCameraTool
- +10520+ = CameraWalkTool
- +10509+ = CameraZoomTool
- +10526+ = CameraZoomWindowTool
- +21096+ = CircleTool
- +21013+ = ComponentTool
- +21126+ = ComponentCSTool
- +21410+ = DimensionTool
- +21019+ = EraseTool
- +21031+ = FreehandTool
- +21525+ = ExtrudeTool
- +21126+ = SketchCSTool
- +21048+ = MoveTool
- +21024+ = MeasureTool
- +21100+ = OffsetTool
- +21074+ = PaintTool
- +21013+ = PasteTool
- +21095+ = PolyTool
- +21515+ = PositionTextureTool
- +21041+ = PushPullTool
- +21057+ = ProtractorTool
- +21094+ = RectangleTool
- +21129+ = RotateTool
- +21236+ = ScaleTool
- +21022+ = SelectionTool
- +21337+ = SectionPlaneTool
- +21020+ = SketchTool
- +21405+ = TextTool
Sketchup::ToolsObserver.name: ToolsObserver

Sketchup::ToolsObserver#onActiveToolChan.description:
Once you subclass {Sketchup::ToolsObserver} with your unique class, you can
override the {#onActiveToolChanged} method to receive tool change
notifications.
Sketchup::ToolsObserver#onActiveToolChan.name: onActiveToolChanged
parameters:
The ID of the tool. This is a predefined number
unique to a given tool. For example, the Materials Browser is tool_id
21074.

Sketchup::ToolsObserver#onToolStateChang.description:
The {#onToolStateChanged} method is called each time the user performs an
action with a tool. The actual state that is returned is an internal number
that varies tool to tool. If you want to watch existing tools for every
interaction, you will need to experiment with the tool state to determine
which states you care about. There is little consistency tool to tool.
Sketchup::ToolsObserver#onToolStateChang.name: onToolStateChanged
parameters:
The ID of the tool. This is a predefined number
unique to a given tool. For example, the Materials Browser is tool_id
21074.

A number identifying the state the tool just
entered.

Sketchup::UVHelper.description:
The UV Helper class contains methods allowing you to determine the location
(UV coordinates) of a texture on a face. This class is particularly useful
in determining how textures that have been manipulated using the Texture
Tweaker should appear when exported to another file type

Use the Face.get_UVHelper method to create a UVHelper for a given face.
See the TextureWriter class as well.
Sketchup::UVHelper.name: UVHelper

Sketchup::UVHelper#get_back_UVQ.description:
The {#get_back_UVQ} method is used to get the UV texture coordinates on the
back of a face.
Sketchup::UVHelper#get_back_UVQ.name: get_back_UVQ
return: Point where X represents U, Y represents V and Z represents Q.

Sketchup::UVHelper#get_front_UVQ.description:
The {#get_front_UVQ} method is used to get the UV texture coordinates on the
front of a face.
Sketchup::UVHelper#get_front_UVQ.name: get_front_UVQ
return: Point where X represents U, Y represents V and Z represents Q.

Sketchup::Vertex.description: A Vertex. A Vertex represents the end of an Edge or a point inside a Face.
Sketchup::Vertex.name: Vertex

Sketchup::Vertex#common_edge.description:
The common_edge method is used to find a common edge that is defined by this
vertex and another vertex
Sketchup::Vertex#common_edge.name: common_edge
return:
an Edge object common to both vertices if
successful. Returns nil if there is no edge between the
two vertices.

Sketchup::Vertex#curve_interior?.description:
The {#curve_interior?} method is used to determine if this vertex is on the
interior of a Curve.
Sketchup::Vertex#curve_interior?.name: curve_interior?

Sketchup::Vertex#edges.description: The edges method is used to retrieve an Array of edges that use the Vertex.
Sketchup::Vertex#edges.name: edges
return: an Array of edge objects if successful

Sketchup::Vertex#faces.description: The faces method is used to retrieve an Array of faces that use the vertex.
Sketchup::Vertex#faces.name: faces
return:
an Array of faces that use the vertex if
successful

Sketchup::Vertex#loops.description: The loops method is used to retrieve an Array of loops that use the vertex.
Sketchup::Vertex#loops.name: loops
return:
an Array of loops that use the vertex if
successful

Sketchup::Vertex#position.description: The position method is used to retrieve the Point3d position of a vertex.
Sketchup::Vertex#position.name: position
return:
a Point3d object representing the position of
the vertex if successful

Sketchup::Vertex#used_by?.description:
The used_by? method is used to determine if the Vertex is used by a given
Edge or Face.
Sketchup::Vertex#used_by?.name: used_by?
parameters: A Face or Edge ot test against.

Sketchup::View.description:
This class contains methods to manipulate the current point of view of the
model. The drawing methods here (draw_line, draw_polyline, etc) are meant to
be invoked within a tool's Tool.draw method. Calling them outside Tool.draw
will have no effect.

You access the View by calling the Model.active_view method.
Sketchup::View.name: View

Sketchup::View#add_observer.description: The add_observer method is used to add an observer to the current object.
Sketchup::View#add_observer.name: add_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::View#animation=.description:
The animation= method is used to set an animation that is displayed for a
view. See Animation for details on how to create an animation object.
Sketchup::View#animation=.name: animation=

Sketchup::View#average_refresh_time.description:
The average_refresh_time is used to set the average time used to refresh the
current model in the view. This can be used to estimate the frame rate for
an animation.
Sketchup::View#average_refresh_time.name: average_refresh_time

Sketchup::View#camera.description: The camera method is used to retrieve the camera for the view.
Sketchup::View#camera.name: camera

Sketchup::View#camera=.description:
The {#camera=} method is used to set the camera for the view. If a transition
time is given, then it will animate the transition from the current camera
to the new one.
Sketchup::View#camera=.name: camera=

Sketchup::View#center.description:
The center method is used to retrieve the coordinates of the center of the
view in pixels. It is returned as an array of 2 values for x and y.
Sketchup::View#center.name: center

Sketchup::View#corner.description:
The corner method is used to retrieve the coordinates of one of the corners
of the view. The argument is an index between 0 and 3 that identifies which
corner you want. This method returns an array with two integers which are
the coordinates of the corner of the view in the view space. If the view
uses a Camera with a fixed aspect ratio, then the corners are the corners of
the viewing are of the camera which might be different than the actual
corners of the view itself.

The index numbers are as follows:
 - 0: top left,
 - 1: top right,
 - 2: bottom left,
 - 3: bottom right.
Sketchup::View#corner.name: corner
parameters:
A value between (or including) 0 and 3 identifying the
corner whose coordinate you want to retrieve.
return: a 2d array [w,h] representing the screen point

Sketchup::View#draw.description:
The {#draw} method is used to do basic drawing. This method can only be
called from within the {Tool#draw} method of a tool that you implement in
Ruby.

The following constants are all OpenGL terms and have been externalized to
Ruby. Here is a summary of their meanings:

[GL_POINTS]
  Treats each vertex as a single point. Vertex n defines point n. N
  points are drawn.

[GL_LINES]
  Treats each pair of vertices as
  an independent line segment. Vertices 2n-1 and 2n define line n. N/2 lines
  are drawn.

[GL_LINE_STRIP]
  Draws a connected group of line
  segments from the first vertex to the last. Vertices n and n+1 define
  line n. N-1 lines are drawn.

[GL_LINE_LOOP]
  Draws a connected group of line segments from the first vertex to the last,
  then back to the first. Vertices n and n+1 define line n. The last line,
  however, is defined by vertices N and 1. N lines are drawn.

[GL_TRIANGLES]
  Treats each triplet of vertices as an independent
  triangle. Vertices 3n-2, 3n-1, and 3n define triangle n. N/3 triangles are
  drawn.

[GL_TRIANGLE_STRIP]
  Draws a connected group of triangles. One triangle is defined for each
  vertex presented after the first two vertices. For odd n, vertices n, n+1,
  and n+2 define triangle n. For even n, vertices n+1, n, and n+2 define
  triangle n. N-2 triangles are drawn.

[GL_TRIANGLE_FAN]
  Draws a connected group of triangles.
  One triangle is defined for each vertex presented after the first two
  vertices. Vertices 1, n+1, and n+2 define triangle n. N-2 triangles are
  drawn.

[GL_QUADS]
  Treats each group of four vertices as an
  independent quadrilateral. Vertices 4n-3, 4n-2, 4n-1, and 4n define
  quadrilateral n. N/4 quadrilaterals are drawn.

[GL_QUAD_STRIP]
  Draws a connected group of quadrilaterals. One quadrilateral is
  defined for each pair of vertices presented after the first pair.
  Vertices 2n-1, 2n, 2n+2, and 2n+1 define quadrilateral n. N/2-1
  quadrilaterals are drawn. Note that the order in which vertices are used to
  construct a quadrilateral from strip data is different from that used with
  independent data.

[GL_POLYGON]
  Draws a single, convex polygon. Vertices 1
  through N define this polygon.
Sketchup::View#draw.name: draw

Sketchup::View#draw2d.description:
The {#draw2d} method is used to draw in screen space (using 2D screen
coordinates) instead of 3D space.

The second parameter is an {Array} of {Geom::Point3d} objects (or several
individual {Geom::Point3d} objects). These {Geom::Point3d} objects are in
screen space, not 3D space.
The X value corresponds to the number of pixels from the left edge of the
drawing area. The Y value corresponds to the number of pixels down from
the top of the drawing area. The Z value is not used.
Sketchup::View#draw2d.name: draw2d

Sketchup::View#draw_line.description:
The draw_lines method is used to draw disconnected lines.

You must have an even number of points. This method is usually  invoked
within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#draw_line.name: draw_line

Sketchup::View#draw_lines.description:
The draw_lines method is used to draw disconnected lines.

You must have an even number of points. This method is usually  invoked
within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#draw_lines.name: draw_lines

Sketchup::View#draw_points.description:
This method is used to draw points.

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#draw_points.name: draw_points
parameters: Size of the point in pixels.

1 = open square, 2 = filled square, 3 = "+", 4 = "X", 5 = "*",
6 = open triangle, 7 = filled triangle.

Sketchup::View#draw_polyline.description:
The draw_polyline method is used to draw a series of connected line segments
from pt1 to pt2 to pt3, and so on.

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#draw_polyline.name: draw_polyline

Sketchup::View#draw_text.description: This method is used to draw text on the screen and is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool. The {TextVerticalAlignCenter} option will align the text to the center of the height of the first line, not the whole boundingbox of the text. To align around the full bounds of the text, use {#text_bounds} to compute the desired alignment. Example of different vertical alignment and text bounds: rdoc-image:../images/view-draw-text-with-bounds.png
Sketchup::View#draw_text.name: draw_text

Sketchup::View#drawing_color=.description:
The drawing_color method is used to set the color that is used for drawing
to the view.

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#drawing_color=.name: drawing_color=

Sketchup::View#dynamic=.description:
The dynamic= method allows you to degrade visual quality while improving
performance when a model is large and view refresh time is slow. For
example, if you were using a Ruby script to animate the camera through
a large scene, you may want to set dynamic to true during that time.

See also camera.rb which is part of the film and stage ruby
scripts.
Sketchup::View#dynamic=.name: dynamic=

Sketchup::View#field_of_view.description:
The field_of_view method is used get the view's field of view setting, in
degrees.
Sketchup::View#field_of_view.name: field_of_view

Sketchup::View#field_of_view=.description:
The field_of_view= method is used set the view's field of view setting,
in degrees.
Sketchup::View#field_of_view=.name: field_of_view=

Sketchup::View#guess_target.description:
The guess_target method is used to guess at what the user is looking at when
you have a perspective view.

This method is useful when writing a viewing tool. See also camera.rb which
is part of the film and stage ruby scripts.
Sketchup::View#guess_target.name: guess_target
return:
a Point3d object representing the point in the
model that the user is likely interested in.

Sketchup::View#inference_locked?.description:
The inference_locked? method is used to determine if inference locking is on
for the view.
Sketchup::View#inference_locked?.name: inference_locked?

Sketchup::View#inputpoint.description:
The inputpoint method is used to retrieve an input point.

This will normally be used inside one of the mouse event handling methods in
a tool. Usually, it is preferable to create the InputPoint first and then
use the pick method on it.
Sketchup::View#inputpoint.name: inputpoint

Sketchup::View#invalidate.description: The invalidate method is used mark the view as in need of a redraw.
Sketchup::View#invalidate.name: invalidate

Sketchup::View#last_refresh_time.description:
The last_refresh_time method is used to retrieve the time for the last full
view refresh.
Sketchup::View#last_refresh_time.name: last_refresh_time

Sketchup::View#line_stipple=.description:
The line_stipple= method is used to set the line pattern to use for drawing.
The stipple pattern is given as a string.
Valid strings are:
  "." (Dotted Line),
  "-" (Short Dashes Line),
  "_" (Long Dashes Line),
  "-.-" (Dash Dot Dash Line),
  "" (Solid Line).

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#line_stipple=.name: line_stipple=
parameters: A string stipple pattern, such as "-.-"

Sketchup::View#line_width=.description:
The line_width= method is used to set the line width to use for drawing. The
value is a Double indicating the desired width in pixels.

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#line_width=.name: line_width=

Sketchup::View#load_texture.description: Loads a texture to be drawn with {#draw} or {#draw2d}.
Sketchup::View#load_texture.name: load_texture
return: A resource ID referring to the image loaded.

Sketchup::View#lock_inference.description:
The {#lock_inference} method is used to lock or unlock an inference.

This method will typically be called from inside a tool class when the user
presses the shift key or arrow keys.

With no arguments it unlocks all inferences. With one argument it locks
inference based on that passed {Sketchup::InputPoint}'s entities, e.g. along
a {Sketchup::Edge}'s line or a {Sketchup::Face}'s plane. With two arguments,
it locks inference along an axis.
Sketchup::View#lock_inference.name: lock_inference

Sketchup::View#model.description: The model method is used to retrieve the model for the current view.
Sketchup::View#model.name: model

Sketchup::View#pick_helper.description:
The pick_helper method is used to retrieve a pick helper for the view. See
the PickHelper class for information on pick helpers.

This call returns an initialized PickHelper.
Sketchup::View#pick_helper.name: pick_helper

Sketchup::View#pickray.description:
The pickray method is used to retrieve a ray passing through a given screen
position in the viewing direction.
Sketchup::View#pickray.name: pickray

Sketchup::View#pixels_to_model.description:
The pixels_to_model method is used to compute a model size from a pixel size
at a given point.

This method is useful for deciding how big to draw something based on a
desired size in pixels.
Sketchup::View#pixels_to_model.name: pixels_to_model
parameters: A Point3d object where the size will be calculated from.

Sketchup::View#refresh.description: The refresh method is used to immediately force a redraw of the view.
Sketchup::View#refresh.name: refresh

Sketchup::View#release_texture.description:
Releases a texture loaded via {#load_texture}, freeing up it's memory.
It's good practice to do so whenever there is no longer any need for the
resource.

For example, when your tool deactivates you probably want to release your
resources as you don't know if your tool will be used again.
Sketchup::View#release_texture.name: release_texture

Sketchup::View#remove_observer.description:
The remove_observer method is used to remove an observer from the current
object.
Sketchup::View#remove_observer.name: remove_observer
return: true if successful, false if unsuccessful.

Sketchup::View#screen_coords.description:
The screen_coords method is used to retrieve the screen coordinates of the
given point on the screen.

The x and y values returned correspond to the x and y screen coordinates.
Ignore the z values.  If the referenced point is not in the current
viewport,  the x and/or y value may be negative.
Sketchup::View#screen_coords.name: screen_coords
return: A Point3d containing the screen position

Sketchup::View#set_color_from_line.description:
Set the drawing color for the view based on the direction of a line that you
want to draw. These colors will match the axes colors in the SketchUp model
(typically blue for straight up and down, etc.)

This method is usually invoked within the draw method of a tool.
Sketchup::View#set_color_from_line.name: set_color_from_line
parameters: Point3d object representing first point in the line.
Point3d object representing the second point in the line.

Sketchup::View#show_frame.description:
The show_frame method is used to show a frame of an Animation object in the
current view.

You can supply an optional delay in seconds to wait before showing the next
frame. This can be useful to control the speed at which the animation runs.
Sketchup::View#show_frame.name: show_frame

Sketchup::View#text_bounds.description: This method is used to compute the bounds of the text when using {#draw_text}. The bounds are not a tight fit around the top and bottom as they include varying amount of line spacing depending on the font used. The {TextVerticalAlignCenter} option will align the text to the center of the height of the first line, not the whole boundingbox of the text. Example of different vertical alignment and text bounds: rdoc-image:../images/view-draw-text-with-bounds.png
Sketchup::View#text_bounds.name: text_bounds
parameters:
A Point3d object representing a 2D coordinate
in view space.

The text can be customized by providing a hash or
named arguments of options.

Sketchup::View#tooltip=.description:
Set a tooltip to display in the view. This is useful for displaying tooltips
in a tool that you write in Ruby.
Sketchup::View#tooltip=.name: tooltip=

Sketchup::View#vpheight.description:
The vpheight method is used to retrieve the height of the viewport for the
view.
Sketchup::View#vpheight.name: vpheight
return: the height of the viewport in physical pixels.

Sketchup::View#vpwidth.description:
The vpwidth method is used to retrieve the width of the viewport for the
view.
Sketchup::View#vpwidth.name: vpwidth
return: the width of the viewport in physical pixels.

Sketchup::View#write_image.description:
The {#write_image} method is used to write the current view to an image file.

Supported file types are `.png`, `.jpg`, `.jpeg`, `gif`, `.bmp`, `.tif`.
For other file formats  available from the GUI in File > Export > 2D
Graphics, .e.g `.pdf`, use {Sketchup::Model#export}.
Sketchup::View#write_image.name: write_image

Sketchup::View#zoom.description: The zoom method is used to zoom in or out by some zoom factor.
Sketchup::View#zoom.name: zoom
parameters:
A Float zoom factor from 1.0 or larger or an Array or
collection of entities to "zoom extents" around.

Sketchup::View#zoom_extents.description:
The zoom_extents method is used to zoom to the extents about the entire
model, as if the user has selected the zoom extents command from the menu.
Sketchup::View#zoom_extents.name: zoom_extents

Sketchup::ViewObserver.description: This observer interface is implemented to react to view events.
Sketchup::ViewObserver.name: ViewObserver

Sketchup::ViewObserver#onViewChanged.description:
The {#onViewChanged} method is called whenever the view is altered, such as
when the user uses the Pan, Orbit, or Zoom tools are used.
Sketchup::ViewObserver#onViewChanged.name: onViewChanged

LanguageHandler.description:
The LanguageHandler class contains methods used to help make SketchUp
extensions easier to localize across different languages. It looks for
translated resources within the Resources folder in the extension's directory
structure. All translated resources should be located within the appropriate
language folder and encoded in UTF-8. The strings file should include
"key"="value" string pairs in the following format:
LanguageHandler.name: LanguageHandler

LanguageHandler#[].description:
Looks up and returns the localized version of a given string, based on the
language SketchUp is currently running in, and the available translations
in the Resources folder.
parameters: The key for the string to be retrieved.

LanguageHandler#initialize.description: The new method is used to create a new LanguageHandler object.
LanguageHandler#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
The name of the file that contains the localized strings
with their keys in UTF-8 encoding.

LanguageHandler#resource_path.description:
Returns a string containing the path to the given filename if it can be found
in the Resources folder.
LanguageHandler#resource_path.name: resource_path
return: the location of the file in the Resources folder.

LanguageHandler#strings.description: Returns a Hash object containing the localization dictionary.
LanguageHandler#strings.name: strings

SketchupExtension.description:
The SketchupExtension class contains methods allowing you to create and
manipulate SketchUp extensions. Extensions are Ruby scripts that can be
loaded and unloaded using the Extension manager (Extensions panel of the
Preferences dialog box). Generally you should register your ruby scripts as
an extension to give SketchUp users the ability to disable it through the
user interface.

The idea here is to take the ruby script that actually creates your
functionality and place it in a folder somewhere outside of the /Plugins
folder, most commonly a subdirectory like /Plugins/MyExtension. Then
you create a new ruby script inside the /Plugins directory that will
set up the extension entry and load your original script if the user
has your extension turned on.

Here is an example extension loading script. For this example, the
following code would be saved in /Plugins/StairTools.rb, and the
actual plugin itself would live in /Plugins/StairTools/core.rb.

You can find two example extensions that ship with SketchUp,
su_dynamiccomponents.rb and su_sandboxtools.rb, under the /Plugins/ folder.
SketchupExtension.name: SketchupExtension

SketchupExtension#check.description:
Loads the extension, meaning the underlying ruby script is immediately
interpreted. This is the equivalent of checking the extension's checkbox
in the Preferences > Extensions list.
SketchupExtension#check.name: check

SketchupExtension#copyright.description:
The copyright method returns the copyright string which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#copyright.name: copyright

SketchupExtension#copyright=.description:
The copyright= method sets the copyright string which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#copyright=.name: copyright=

SketchupExtension#creator.description:
The creator method returns the creator string which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#creator.name: creator

SketchupExtension#creator=.description:
The creator= method sets the creator string which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#creator=.name: creator=

SketchupExtension#description.description:
The description method returns the long description which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#description.name: description

SketchupExtension#description=.description:
The description= method sets the long description which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#description=.name: description=

SketchupExtension#extension_path.description:
The extension_path method returns the file system path to the extension's
outer rb file.
SketchupExtension#extension_path.name: extension_path
return: the file system path to the extension

SketchupExtension#id.description: The id method returns the Extension Warehouse ID string.
SketchupExtension#id.name: id

SketchupExtension#initialize.description:
The new method is used to create a new SketchupExtension object. Note
that once the extension object is created, it will not appear in the
Extension Manager dialog until your register it with the
Sketchup.register_extension method.
SketchupExtension#initialize.name: initialize
parameters:
The relative path to the script that loads your
plugin.

SketchupExtension#load_on_start?.description: Returns whether the extension is set to load when SketchUp starts up.
SketchupExtension#load_on_start?.name: load_on_start?

SketchupExtension#loaded?.description:
Returns whether the extension is currently loaded, meaning the actual ruby
script that implements the extension has been evaluated.
SketchupExtension#loaded?.name: loaded?

SketchupExtension#name.description:
The name method returns the name which appears for
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#name.name: name

SketchupExtension#name=.description:
The name= method sets the name which appears for
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#name=.name: name=

SketchupExtension#registered?.description:
Returns whether the extension has been registered via
Sketchup.register_extension.
SketchupExtension#registered?.name: registered?

SketchupExtension#uncheck.description:
Unloads the extension. This is the equivalent of unchecking the extension's
checkbox in the Preferences > Extensions list.

Note that technically the extension is not "unloaded" in the sense that it
stops running during the current SketchUp session, but the next time the
user restarts SketchUp, the extension will not be active.
SketchupExtension#uncheck.name: uncheck

SketchupExtension#version.description:
The version method returns the version which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#version.name: version

SketchupExtension#version=.description:
The version method sets the version which appears beneath
an extension inside the Extensions Manager dialog.
SketchupExtension#version=.name: version=

SketchupExtension#version_id.description: The version_id method returns the Extension Warehouse Version ID string.
SketchupExtension#version_id.name: version_id
return: the Extension Warehouse Version ID string
